           <p data-reactid="1490">
            <!-- react-text: 1491 -->
            This is an information service. By browsing on the website and/or using our search tools, you are asking RateCity to provide you with information about products from multiple financial institutions. We will try to show you a range of products in response to your request for information. The search results do not include all providers and may not compare all features relevant to you, for further details refer to our FSCG. We are not a credit provider, and in giving you product information we are not making any suggestion or recommendation to you about a particular credit product. If you decide to apply for a product, you will deal directly with a financial institution, and not with RateCity. Rates and product information should be confirmed with the relevant financial institution, and you should review the PDS before you decide to purchase. See our
            <!-- /react-text -->
            <a data-reactid="1492" href="//www.ratecity.com.au/terms-of-use#toc_4" rel="nofollow">
             terms of use
            </a>
            <!-- react-text: 1493 -->
            for further details. This advice is general and has not taken into account your objectives, financial situation or needs. Consider whether this advice is right for you. Any recommendations made about a financial product are general advice only and has not taken into account your particular needs and circumstances. You should consider the Product Disclosure Statement to determine if the product is suitable for you before you decide to purchase it.

Choosing the right one will depend on your circumstances, spending and saving habits, as well as your saving goals. Here&rsquo;s what you need to know about ING savings accounts.</p>\n<h3>Who is ING?</h3>\n<p>ING has been trading in Australia since 1999, making them a relatively new player in the banking scene. However, their parent company, ING Group, has a much longer history, originating in the Netherlands and tracing back as far as 1845.</p>\n<p>Nonetheless, ING offers Australian consumers one alternative to the big four banks. They have only one branch, located in Sydney and advertised as the &ldquo;ING Lounge&rdquo;. The majority of their customers&rsquo; banking is done online, with the use of both online banking and the ING mobile app.</p>\n<h3>What is a savings account?</h3>\n<p>A savings account is an additional bank account that many consumers hold, in addition to their everyday transaction accounts.</p>\n<p>The reason for this is that a savings account is a separate account to store and accrue money that you wish to save. We all know that if we leave our savings in our transaction account, they often don&rsquo;t stay savings for long.</p>\n<p>Having a savings account makes it easier to keep track of your savings, and harder to &ldquo;accidentally&rdquo; dip in when money gets tight. Many savings account also deliberately come without ATM access, making it even harder to spend your savings (although certainly not impossible.)</p>\n<h3>What should I look for in a savings account?</h3>\n<p>The goal of your savings account is &ndash; unsurprisingly &ndash; to help you maximise the money you save, while minimising your chances of spending your savings.</p>\n<p>The main thing to look for in a savings account is a high interest rate. You want the money that you are saving to accrue as much interest as possible, in order to grow your savings. Many banks offer savings account with introductory or &ldquo;honeymoon&rdquo; interest rates for the first three months or so. These may seem enticing, but remember to check the base interest rate too, as this is what you&rsquo;re signing up for in the long term.</p>\n<p>You should also check for any additional fees. These might include account-keeping, transaction or even deposit fees. Make sure that you&rsquo;re not signing up for an account that will drain your savings in fees.</p>\n<h3>What can I expect from an ING savings account?</h3>\n<p>ING has won multiple awards for their savings accounts, which is a promising start. Because ING banking is done predominantly online, overall operations costs are lower than a traditional &ldquo;bricks and mortar&rdquo; bank. These savings can then be passed onto consumers, with lower account-keeping fees and higher interest rates.</p>\n<p>ING offers a range of savings options, including traditional savings accounts and term deposits. Start by comparing savings options and their interest rates, and make sure to take into account both the standard and variable interest rates.</p>\n<h3>What&rsquo;s the difference between standard and variable interest rates?</h3>\n<p>The variable interest rate is another name for a honeymoon or bonus interest rate. As previously mentioned, this higher interest rate could be applied to your savings account for the first few months. This is common practice among many banks, to entice new customers to switch banks.</p>\n<p>A variable interest rate could also be applied to your savings account as an incentive for certain activities. For example, your bank might apply the variable interest rate if you deposit a certain amount of money each month, and make no withdrawals. These activities encourage more savings for you, and also mean that the bank is handling more of your money, so they are happy to incentivise them.</p>\n<p>The standard interest rate is, to put it simply, the interest rate on your savings account when the variable rate no longer applies. This could be because you&rsquo;ve reached the end of the honeymoon period, or you haven&rsquo;t met the required activity to be rewarded with the variable interest rate. Make sure to take the standard interest rate into account when considering a savings account, as it is usually significantly lower than the variable interest rate.</p>\n<p>It&rsquo;s also important to remember that interest rates - both standard and variable - are at the bank&rsquo;s discretion and can change at any time.</p>\n<h3>Is an ING savings account right for me?</h3>\n<p>Whether a particular bank or account is the right option for you will always depend on your personal circumstances, income and spending and saving habits.</p>\n<p>If you&rsquo;re considering an ING savings account, be sure to compare this account with other competitors too, to make sure you&rsquo;re getting the right account for you.</p>\n<p>If you prefer to bank online, ING could be a good option for you. But make sure to consider all of your options before making a decision.</p>","hasContent":true,"hasRepaymentWidget":false,"logo":"//production-ultimate-assets.ratecity.com.au/ratecity/image/upload/v1502328878/company/nz4eowupbneh7xupca6x.png","metadata":{"google":{},"og":{},"textContent":"<p>ING offers two standard savings accounts – Savings Maximiser and Savings Accelerator. Here&rsquo;s a helpful guide on savings accounts in Australia.</p>\n<h3>What is a savings account?</h3>\n<p>A savings account helps you grow your savings by offering a compound interest rate that is higher than the rate on your everyday transaction account.</p>\n<p>Designed to accrue money, a savings account usually does not come with a key card for ATM access. To withdraw money, you need to transfer it across to a linked transaction account.</p>\n<p>There are some pros and cons to weigh up before deciding whether a savings account is right for you.</p>\n<p><strong>The pros:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>High interest rates &ndash; </strong>Savings accounts generally come with competitive interest rates that help you reach your financial goals faster, especially given it&rsquo;s a compound interest rate on offer. Many lenders also offer bonus rates for an introductory period, or if certain conditions are met.</li>\n<li><strong>Investment protection &ndash; </strong>Unlike other investments, which come with some risk, a savings account is unlikely to give you a negative return. The government also protects deposits of up to $250,000 in authorised deposit-taking institutions (ADIs). This means that if your lender is an ADI and it goes bankrupt, your money is safe.</li>\n<li><strong>No lock-in period &ndash; </strong>Savings accounts in Australia typically don&rsquo;t have a lock-in period, so you can move your money at any point. Some people use this feature to opt in and out of different products &ndash; taking advantage of bonus introductory rates on the market, then switching products once the introductory period is over.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>The cons:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Fluctuating interest rates &ndash; </strong>Savings account interest rates are variable, which means they fluctuate &ndash; and potentially decrease &ndash; depending on the <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">cash rate</a>.</li>\n<li><strong>Conditions around bonus interest rates &ndash; </strong>Although bonus interest rates are appealing, they often come with conditions such as a limited number of withdrawals, a minimum monthly deposit, or getting a linked transaction account with the same lender. Similarly, bonus introductory rates only last for a certain period before the account reverts to a lower base rate. Take the time to check what conditions are attached to any bonus rate on offer.</li>\n<li><strong>Temptation to spend</strong> <strong>&ndash;</strong> Most savings accounts allow you to transfer your funds into your transaction account for easy access. While some prefer this flexibility, others may find it a temptation to spend impulsively, rather than save.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3>Are there alternatives to a savings account?</h3>\n<p>One alternative to a savings account, which can also come with competitive interest rates, is a term deposit account.</p>\n<p>A term deposit invests your money for a certain period &ndash; usually between one month to five years &ndash; at a fixed rate of interest. It suits savers who want to lock away their money for a period, although the downside is if you want to access your money before the term is over, you may need to pay a penalty.</p>\n<p>In many cases, banks and credit unions require a minimum amount to invest your money in a term deposit account.</p>\n<h3>What should you look for when choosing a savings account?</h3>\n<p>It&rsquo;s always worth comparing different savings accounts on the market and what they offer. Key questions to ask include:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Is the interest rate offered the most competitive on the market?</strong> You can use the <span><a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/compare\">RateCity website</a></span> to compare different rates on the market.</li>\n<li><strong>What is the base rate?</strong> An advertised introductory rate only lasts for a certain period. Check the base rate to find out how much interest you will earn once the introductory period is over. This also applies to bonus rates that come with special conditions, as the base rate is what you will earn if those conditions aren&rsquo;t met.</li>\n<li><strong>How accessible is the account?</strong> It&rsquo;s worth finding out if the lender allows you to manage your savings account online, if there is a cheque facility, or if you need to open a transaction account with the same lender to access your money.</li>\n<li><strong>What fees do they charge?</strong> Take the time to check what fees come attached to any product you are considering. You can find them on the product&rsquo;s terms and conditions.</li>\n</ul>\n<h3>Savings accounts at Bankwest</h3>\n<p><a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Bankwest</a> offers a range of savings accounts with different features that can help you reach your financial goals.</p>\n<p>For more information, you can visit the <span><a href=\"https://www.bankwest.com.au/\">Bankwest website</a></span> and follow the online prompts. If you prefer, you can also <span><a href=\"https://www.bankwest.com.au/contact-us\">call</a></span> or speak to someone in person at a <span><a href=\"https://www.bankwest.com.au/find-us\">Bankwest branch.</a></span></p>\n<p>Keep in mind that you will need to have certain documents handy when you apply, such as your banking details, identification documents (for example, a driver&rsquo;s licence or passport) or tax file number. A full list of what you need is available on the Bankwest website.</p>","hasContent":true,"hasRepaymentWidget":false,"logo":"//production-ultimate-assets.ratecity.com.au/ratecity/image/upload/v1525908237/company/stoo4xrufwv9iofl8ixx.png","metadata":{"google":{},"og":{},"textContent":"<p><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\">Bankwest</a> offers several savings account options. As a mutual, its members are its owners and have a say in how the bank is run.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Heritage Bank offers a variety of products and services to its members, including personal loans, home loans, credit cards, term deposits, insurance products and wealth planning.</span></p>","companyInformation":[{"content":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Heritage Bank has a range of personal loans to suit different borrower profiles and preferences. They can also opt for either a fixed or variable interest rate. Borrowers can take out a Newcastle Permanent personal loan for periods between one and seven years.</span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A Newcastle Permanent personal loan offers a range of attractive features, including flexible repayments and no penalties for paying out the loan early. The flexible repayment schedule means that you can make weekly, fortnightly or monthly repayments. This feature is useful as the more frequently you make repayments, the less interest you&rsquo;ll end up paying in the long run.</span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Being able to pay out the loan early without penalty is also a plus. There&rsquo;s no redraw facility attached to these loans, so any extra repayments cannot be re-accessed once paid into the loan.</span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Newcastle Permanent personal loans can be used for a range of different purposes including:</span></p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">New and used cars</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Motorcycles</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Boats</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Student loans</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Debt consolidation</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Renovations</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Shares</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Holidays</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Medical bills</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Weddings and events</span></li>\r\n</ul>","order":"0","title":"Features of a Newcastle Permanent personal loan"},{"content":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Customers looking to contact Newcastle Permanent customer service can call the bank, send an online enquiry form or pop into a branch in NSW. As an established brand and one of Australia&rsquo;s biggest banks, ANZ doesn&rsquo;t have to undercut competitors with low rates, so interest rates tend to sit in the mid-range.</p>\r\n<p>As is the case for many home loan lenders, lower interest rates are afforded to owner-occupiers than to investors, while borrowers paying back principal and interest get lower interest rates than those paying back interest only. Likewise, borrowers with lower LVRs (loan-to-value ratios) typically get lower interest rates than borrowers with higher LVRs.</p>\r\n<p>ANZ also offers different interest rates depending on whether the borrower applies for a variable mortgage, a one-year fixed-rate mortgage, two-year fixed-rate mortgage, three-year fixed rate-mortgage or five-year fixed rate mortgage.</p>","order":"1","title":"ANZ home loan rates"},{"content":"<p>In a varied and ever-changing mortgage market, ANZ has the advantage of being established and well-known &ndash; so customers tend to see the bank as being a reliable option for home loans.</p>\r\n<p>As you might expect from one of the big four banks, ANZ offers home loan products to suit a wide range of borrowers, ranging from basic owner-occupier home loans to more specialist loans including reverse mortgages, bridging loans and others. Commonwealth Bank was founded in 1911 by the Andrew Fisher Labour Government. Unlike any other financial institutions in Australia, it was the first and only bank in Australia to receive a Federal Government guarantee which provided security for the Bank to carry out both savings and general bank trading business. The Bank became a public company in 1991 and underwent three stages of privatisation until 1996. The Commonwealth Bank brand has grown to become one of the best recognised in the financial services industry. Their other award-winning brands include Colonial First State investments and retail broker Commonwealth Securities (CommSec). It can also be used as an emergency fund, should you need the extra cash.</p>\n<p>A savings account generally has no monthly fee, along with a competitive and ongoing interest rate. There are different types of savings accounts, some with withdrawal restrictions and others with a bit more withdrawal flexibility.</p>\n<p>Deciding which savings account is for you depends on your savings plan.</p>\n<h3>Commonwealth Bank savings accounts</h3>\n<p>Whatever you&rsquo;re saving up for, be it a car, a house or a trip abroad, <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Commonwealth Bank</a> probably has a savings account for you.</p>\n<p><strong>NetBank Saver</strong></p>\n<p>Commonwealth Bank&rsquo;s NetBank Saver account provides unlimited transfers to and from a CommBank everyday transaction account (called the Complete Access account).</p>\n<p><strong>GoalSaver</strong></p>\n<p>This GoalSaver savings account rewards you every time you reach a particular savings goal. Most of us already have a savings account in some form, but may not be using it to its fullest potential. </span></p>\n<p><span>Depositing money into a savings account for future access might seem like a no-brainer, however there&rsquo;s now more to the art of saving money due to the huge choice of savings accounts available. </span></p>\n<p><span>The type of savings account you choose is dependent on your savings goals and how you spend your money. No two savings accounts are created equal.</span></p>\n<p><span>For example, if you wanted to split your income between an amount for saving and a budget for spending, you could do this by using different savings accounts. </span></p>\n<h3>Savings accounts v transaction accounts</h3>\n<p><span>Regular transaction accounts are good for spending. A transaction account (because you&rsquo;re likely to use it frequently) generally has no or low monthly account-keeping fees.</span></p>\n<p><span>Many transaction accounts offer you the choice of a debit card, along with a regular bank card and free use of specific ATMs throughout Australia. </span></p>\n<p><span>These extra benefits are designed so that you can access your money regularly and at little or no cost. The downside is they generally don&rsquo;t pay a good rate of interest on your savings principal.</span></p>\n<p><span>That&rsquo;s OK because there are savings accounts available that are designed for saving not spending. These differ in the fees and charges associated with the type of account. </span></p>\n<p><span>Savings accounts that are specifically for parking money may have small disincentives so you&rsquo;re less likely to withdraw your money. </span></p>\n<p><span>A common type of non-spending savings account is a term deposit. Other interest-bearing savings accounts include reward savers, esvaers, isavers and netbank accounts.</span></p>\n<p><span>These accounts pay a variable base rate of interest and often a bonus rate too. Typically, a bank savings account will offer higher interest rates than a transaction account, and will have mechanisms in place to make your money more difficult to access. </span></p>\n<p><span>Many people open an online savings account in conjunction with their everyday transaction account, transferring funds into the savings account regularly to take advantage of the superior interest rate. </span></p>\n<h3>What different bank accounts are available?</h3>\n<p><span>If you&rsquo;re on the hunt for the best savings account, most financial institutions like Citibank will have multiple options available. High-interest savings accounts can be a convenient, easy way to increase your wealth, without exposing it to market risk. It is important to note, however, these accounts are generally not as accessible as traditional transactional accounts, and often require a minimum deposit amount when opening. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Transactional account &ndash;</span></strong><span> These bank accounts are set up to make managing the money you use on a day-to-day basis simple. A term deposit keeps your money in an account for a set period of time. You won&rsquo;t be able to access your funds during that period, but you will earn a fixed rate of interest on this money. </span></li>\n</ul>\n<h3>What should I look for when choosing a savings account?</h3>\n<p><span>If you&rsquo;re in the market for a savings account from Citibank or any other financial institution, there are several factors you should consider before signing the dotted line:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong><span>What&rsquo;s the interest rate? &ndash;</span></strong><span> The savings account interest rate should be a key factor when deciding upon which account is the best fit for you. Read the fine print, and make sure you&rsquo;re comfortable with the interest rate.</span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Are there fees? &ndash;</span></strong><span> Regular admin and account-keeping fees can chew into any interest you&rsquo;ve earned on your account. It is an account separate from your everyday transaction account where you can set aside money for your savings plan. It can also be used as an emergency fund, should you need the extra cash.</p>\n<p>A savings account generally has no monthly fee, along with a competitive and ongoing interest rate. There are different types of savings accounts, some with withdrawal restrictions and others with a bit more withdrawal flexibility.</p>\n<p>Deciding which savings account is for you depends on your savings plan.</p>\n<h3>What are the types of HSBC savings accounts?</h3>\n<p>Many banks, including <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/hsbc\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">HSBC</a>, offer certain types of savings accounts that would best suit your specific saving plans, whether you want to buy a gadget, a car, a house&mdash;or even something as simple as a nice pair of shoes.</p>\n<p><strong>High-interest savings accounts</strong></p>\n<p>High-interest savings accounts usually offer relatively high interest rates and often don&rsquo;t have account service fees either. Commonly, there are certain conditions you have to meet if you want to earn the highest level of interest. These conditions can come in the form of meeting a certain net balance requirement or having withdrawal restrictions. But if you do meet the conditions, you&rsquo;re likely to become a better saver and meet your savings goals faster.</p>\n<p>HSBC offers savings accounts that do require a certain net balance before interest is paid, while other accounts will not pay you interest if you withdraw.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Some HSBC accounts also offer higher interest rates that directly correspond to how much money you put in. This encourages customers to put in more money so they can benefit from a higher interest rate, too.</p>\n<p><strong>Minimum-deposit savings account</strong></p>\n<p>This is also a common type of savings account offered in banks. HSBC has its own name for this, of course, but it essentially functions the same way. With a minimum-deposit savings account, you will only receive interest &ndash; or even a bonus interest, depending on the specific product &ndash; if you meet a minimum deposit requirement.</p>\n<p>Many lenders also have a type of savings account that will require you to increase your net balance by a particular amount by the last business day of every month. Failure to do so usually means you will not be paid the interest rate for that month and you might even be faced a penalty or fee.</p>\n<p>The good news is that this gives you an incentive to consistently contribute, which will in turn boost your savings in the long run. Regularly contributing to this account also ensures that your savings goals will be met eventually &ndash; and it will make you a better saver in the long run, too.</p>\n<p><strong>Term deposit account</strong></p>\n<p>A term deposit account would be a good option for customers who are looking for a fixed interest rate for a fixed period of time (often called a &lsquo;term&rsquo;). Whatever amount is deposited there will stay in the account for the entire term, which could be anywhere from one month to five years. Over this period of time, the interest rate is guaranteed to remain the same.</p>\n<p>You may only withdraw the amount you have placed into this account at the end of the nominated period. However, if you do choose to withdraw before the nominated period, there are usually penalties attached. This is ideal for customers who want to protect their investments from the fluctuations of the share market.</p>\n<p><strong>Standard savings account</strong></p>\n<p>HSBC, like many other banks, also offers an everyday savings account. Although the interest rates aren&rsquo;t as high as other types of savings accounts, getting a standard savings account is still a good way to start off your financial planning.</p>\n<p>A good number of HSBC&rsquo;s various savings accounts allow you easy access to your money. Their online banking system allows you to monitor and manage your finances from anywhere, anytime, be it through a laptop or a mobile phone.</p>\n<p>RateCity has its very own <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/hsbc\">HSBC savings account interest calculator</a> should you be interested in looking at different borrowing scenarios. You may also compare the HSBC savings accounts with other products to see what would best suit your financial goals.</p>\n<p>The HSBC website also offers an <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://partners.leadfusion.com/tools/hsbc2/savings02/tool.fcs\">online tool</a> which will help you figure out how much your savings will be worth should you get an HSBC savings account. This could help you figure out which savings account would best suit your financial goals or savings plans.</p>\n<p>They also have another <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://partners.leadfusion.com/tools/hsbc2/savings13/tool.fcs\">online tool</a> which will help you determine how much your spending reductions would be worth in the long run. It could help you see what to spend less on in order to tighten your budget. With this money management tool, you will get a better idea on how the little things you spend on add up to substantial amounts of money that you&rsquo;re better off saving, instead.</p>","hasContent":true,"hasRepaymentWidget":false,"logo":"//production-ultimate-assets.ratecity.com.au/ratecity/image/upload/v1522885888/company/c3rapnnwesivxasvjnpw.png","metadata":{"google":{},"og":{},"textContent":"<p><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/hsbc\">HSBC</a> offers two savings accounts, neither of which have minimum balance or charge monthly fees. Therefore, you should be comfortable with completing your application and sending through your documentation using online means, rather than visiting a branch. The fact that UBank is a branch-free bank means their overheads are lower, and that rolls down to their products. If avoiding fees and getting the best rate is your highest priority (rather than product features and face to face service) then UBank is a lender worth considering.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div>\n<div>\n<div class=\"breakout breakout-tip\">\n<div class=\"breakout-heading\">\n<p class=\"breakout-title\">SPECIAL OFFER</p>\n<p class=\"breakout-title\">UBank Value Offer</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"breakout-body\">\n<p>Enjoy a homeloan with $0 application fee, $0 ongoing fees and redraw facilities available. It is an account separate from your everyday transaction account where you can set aside money for your savings plan. It can also be used as an emergency fund, should you need the extra cash.</p>\n<p>A savings account generally has no monthly fee, along with a competitive and ongoing interest rate. There are different types of savings accounts, some with withdrawal restrictions and others with a bit more withdrawal flexibility.</p>\n<p>Deciding which savings account is for you depends on your savings plan.</p>\n<h3>What are the types of HSBC savings accounts?</h3>\n<p>Many banks, including <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/hsbc\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">HSBC</a>, offer certain types of savings accounts that would best suit your specific saving plans, whether you want to buy a gadget, a car, a house&mdash;or even something as simple as a nice pair of shoes.</p>\n<p><strong>High-interest savings accounts</strong></p>\n<p>High-interest savings accounts usually offer relatively high interest rates and often don&rsquo;t have account service fees either. Commonly, there are certain conditions you have to meet if you want to earn the highest level of interest. These conditions can come in the form of meeting a certain net balance requirement or having withdrawal restrictions. But if you do meet the conditions, you&rsquo;re likely to become a better saver and meet your savings goals faster.</p>\n<p>HSBC offers savings accounts that do require a certain net balance before interest is paid, while other accounts will not pay you interest if you withdraw.&nbsp;</p>\n<p>Some HSBC accounts also offer higher interest rates that directly correspond to how much money you put in. This encourages customers to put in more money so they can benefit from a higher interest rate, too.</p>\n<p><strong>Minimum-deposit savings account</strong></p>\n<p>This is also a common type of savings account offered in banks. HSBC has its own name for this, of course, but it essentially functions the same way. With a minimum-deposit savings account, you will only receive interest &ndash; or even a bonus interest, depending on the specific product &ndash; if you meet a minimum deposit requirement.</p>\n<p>Many lenders also have a type of savings account that will require you to increase your net balance by a particular amount by the last business day of every month. Failure to do so usually means you will not be paid the interest rate for that month and you might even be faced a penalty or fee.</p>\n<p>The good news is that this gives you an incentive to consistently contribute, which will in turn boost your savings in the long run. Regularly contributing to this account also ensures that your savings goals will be met eventually &ndash; and it will make you a better saver in the long run, too.</p>\n<p><strong>Term deposit account</strong></p>\n<p>A term deposit account would be a good option for customers who are looking for a fixed interest rate for a fixed period of time (often called a &lsquo;term&rsquo;). Whatever amount is deposited there will stay in the account for the entire term, which could be anywhere from one month to five years. Over this period of time, the interest rate is guaranteed to remain the same.</p>\n<p>You may only withdraw the amount you have placed into this account at the end of the nominated period. However, if you do choose to withdraw before the nominated period, there are usually penalties attached. This is ideal for customers who want to protect their investments from the fluctuations of the share market.</p>\n<p><strong>Standard savings account</strong></p>\n<p>HSBC, like many other banks, also offers an everyday savings account. Although the interest rates aren&rsquo;t as high as other types of savings accounts, getting a standard savings account is still a good way to start off your financial planning.</p>\n<p>A good number of HSBC&rsquo;s various savings accounts allow you easy access to your money. Their online banking system allows you to monitor and manage your finances from anywhere, anytime, be it through a laptop or a mobile phone.</p>\n<p>RateCity has its very own <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/hsbc\">HSBC savings account interest calculator</a> should you be interested in looking at different borrowing scenarios. Personal loans with terms between six months and two years come with a variable rate. Loans with terms between three and five years are fixed-rate loans, meaning that your interest rate will remain the same for the entire term of the personal loan.</span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ratesetter personal loans come with personalised interest rates, which means different borrowers get different interest rates, depending on their credit history, credit score, employment status, cash flow and loan amount. </span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ratesetter personal loans come with an upfront establishment fee and borrowers will pay ongoing loan fees. There are no exit fees or early repayment penalties.</span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Before applying for a Ratesetter personal loan, always do your research and compare your options to make sure you&rsquo;re getting a personal loan that suits your budget, needs and lifestyle.</span></p>","order":"4","title":"RateSetter personal loans review"}],"cons":["Upfront fees","No redraw facility","Higher rate for customers with below-average credit history"],"count":8,"hasContent":true,"logo":"//production-ultimate-assets.ratecity.com.au/ratecity/image/upload/v1480050032/company/eafw1bwmiftiegq8jqln.png","metadata":{"category":["Personal Loans - Company Page","/personal-loans/ratesetter"],"google":{},"og":{},"textContent":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Unlike a traditional bank, <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/ratesetter\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Ratesetter</a> is an ASIC-regulated peer-to-peer or marketplace lender. Most of us already have a savings account in some form, but may not be using it to its fullest potential. </span></p>\n<p><span>Depositing money into a savings account for future access might seem like a no-brainer, however there&rsquo;s now more to the art of saving money due to the huge choice of savings accounts available. </span></p>\n<p><span>The type of savings account you choose is dependent on your savings goals and how you spend your money. No two savings accounts are created equal.</span></p>\n<p><span>For example, if you wanted to split your income between an amount for saving and a budget for spending, you could do this by using different savings accounts. </span></p>\n<h3>Savings accounts v transaction accounts</h3>\n<p><span>Regular transaction accounts are good for spending. A transaction account (because you&rsquo;re likely to use it frequently) generally has no or low monthly account-keeping fees.</span></p>\n<p><span>Many transaction accounts offer you the choice of a debit card, along with a regular bank card and free use of specific ATMs throughout Australia. </span></p>\n<p><span>These extra benefits are designed so that you can access your money regularly and at little or no cost. The downside is they generally don&rsquo;t pay a good rate of interest on your savings principal.</span></p>\n<p><span>That&rsquo;s OK because there are savings accounts available that are designed for saving not spending. These differ in the fees and charges associated with the type of account. </span></p>\n<p><span>Savings accounts that are specifically for parking money may have small disincentives so you&rsquo;re less likely to withdraw your money. </span></p>\n<p><span>A common type of non-spending savings account is a term deposit. Other interest-bearing savings accounts include reward savers, esvaers, isavers and netbank accounts.</span></p>\n<p><span>These accounts pay a variable base rate of interest and often a bonus rate too. The rate of interest, minimum opening and ongoing deposits depends on what type of savings account you opt for.</span></p>\n<h3>How do I choose a NAB savings account?</h3>\n<p><span><a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/nab\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">NAB</a> understands the nuances of saving money and offers a diversity of savings accounts to cater for a range of needs.</span></p>\n<p><span>NAB has select savings accounts that are designed for the saver and spender within us all. Products like a <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/citibank\">Citibank</a> savings account can help you reach short- and long-term financial goals. </span></p>\n<p><span>However, there are some savings account limitations you should be aware of before signing the dotted line. We&rsquo;re going to look at the key traits of products like <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/citibank\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Citibank</a> savings accounts, and how these play an important role in any saver&rsquo;s broader financial strategy. </span></p>\n<h3>How does a savings account work?</h3>\n<p><span>Savings account are designed to help your money grow, without exposing funds to market risk. Typically, a bank savings account will offer higher interest rates than a transaction account, and will have mechanisms in place to make your money more difficult to access. </span></p>\n<p><span>Many people open an online savings account in conjunction with their everyday transaction account, transferring funds into the savings account regularly to take advantage of the superior interest rate. </span></p>\n<h3>What different bank accounts are available?</h3>\n<p><span>If you&rsquo;re on the hunt for the best savings account, most financial institutions like Citibank will have multiple options available. Bank account comparison can be difficult, but it&rsquo;s important to test the market so you have the right product to suit your financial goals. </span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong><span>Savings account &ndash;</span></strong><span> If you&rsquo;re looking for a way to store money you won&rsquo;t need straight away, a savings account could be an ideal solution. High-interest savings accounts can be a convenient, easy way to increase your wealth, without exposing it to market risk. It is important to note, however, these accounts are generally not as accessible as traditional transactional accounts, and often require a minimum deposit amount when opening. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Transactional account &ndash;</span></strong><span> These bank accounts are set up to make managing the money you use on a day-to-day basis simple. Your money can be easily accessed via debit cards, ATMs or the internet to meet regular expenses, although these accounts typically offer inferior interest rates when compared to savings account options. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Term deposits &ndash;</span></strong><span> These financial products are set up a little differently to traditional bank accounts, and there are advantages and disadvantages. A term deposit keeps your money in an account for a set period of time. You won&rsquo;t be able to access your funds during that period, but you will earn a fixed rate of interest on this money. </span></li>\n</ul>\n<h3>What should I look for when choosing a savings account?</h3>\n<p><span>If you&rsquo;re in the market for a savings account from Citibank or any other financial institution, there are several factors you should consider before signing the dotted line:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong><span>What&rsquo;s the interest rate? &ndash;</span></strong><span> The savings account interest rate should be a key factor when deciding upon which account is the best fit for you. It&rsquo;s important to note interest rates vary. Some financial institutions offer superior rates as an &lsquo;introductory bonus&rsquo; that expire after a few months. Read the fine print, and make sure you&rsquo;re comfortable with the interest rate.</span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Are there fees? &ndash;</span></strong><span> Regular admin and account-keeping fees can chew into any interest you&rsquo;ve earned on your account. Test the market and make sure you&rsquo;ve selected a savings account with fees that you can manage, and that won&rsquo;t jeopardise your ability to earn interest. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>What are the minimum and maximum account balances? &ndash;</span></strong><span> Many high-interest savings accounts have minimum and maximum account balances you&rsquo;re required to uphold. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Will it require a linked account? &ndash;</span></strong><span> Many savings accounts require a linked transactional account, which will help the account owners manage their funds. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Is the account offered by an authorised deposit-taking institution (ADI)? &ndash;</span></strong><span> These accounts are regulated by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority (APRA) and authorised by the government to offer bank account products to consumers. </span></li>\n</ul>\n<h3>What are the pros and cons of savings accounts?</h3>\n<p><span>The best savings accounts can find a place in many people&rsquo;s personal financial plan, but it&rsquo;s important to be aware of the positives and negatives of these financial products.&nbsp; </span></p>\n<p><strong><span>Pros</span></strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong><span>Higher interest rate &ndash;</span></strong><span> Savings accounts provide an effective way to boost your account, typically offering higher interest rates than normal transactional accounts. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Accessibility &ndash;</span></strong><span> Savings accounts generally let you withdraw money whenever you want, however you may lose bonus interest when making withdrawals. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Features &ndash; </span></strong><span>Many savings accounts offer features like automatic savings plans, which can potentially make it easier to manage your personal finances. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Relatively safe &ndash;</span></strong><span> If your savings account is opened with an ADI, the government will guarantee up to $250,000 if the lender goes bust. </span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong><span>Cons </span></strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong><span>Variable interest rates &ndash; </span></strong><span>Savings account interest rates are subject to change, and depend upon announcements from the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) and each lender&rsquo;s policies. Potentially, this could see your savings account receiving a lower interest rate down the track. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>Accessibility &ndash;</span></strong><span> The temptation to spend money in a highly accessible savings account might be high, which reduces the likelihood that you&rsquo;ll save it. </span></li>\n<li><strong><span>No lock-in periods &ndash;</span></strong><span> This can potentially reduce the incentive to commit to regular deposits.</span></li>\n</ul>","hasContent":true,"hasRepaymentWidget":false,"logo":"//production-ultimate-assets.ratecity.com.au/ratecity/image/upload/v1506319727/company/mldtlhvwzr3xhimwqel7.png","metadata":{"google":{},"og":{},"textContent":"<p><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/citibank\">Citibank</a> gives customers the choice of two savings accounts – Online Saver and Ultimate Saver. Thanks to lower overheads, it can pass savings on to customers in the form of lower interest rates.</span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">While its interest rates tend to be very low to moderately low, upfront fees can be moderately high &ndash; including fees such as valuation fees and legal fees. On the other hand, ongoing fees are usually very low.</span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Homestar Finance&rsquo;s home loan interest rates differ depending on the type of borrower. Typically, interest rates follow a particular pricing structure:</span></p>\r\n<ul>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Owner-occupiers paying principal and interest (lowest rate)</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Owner-occupiers paying interest only OR investors paying principal and interest (second-lowest rate)</span></li>\r\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Investors paying interest only (highest rate)</span></li>\r\n</ul>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Variable home loans also tend to attract lower interest rates &ndash; at least initially &ndash; than fixed home loans.</span></p>","order":"1","title":"Homestar Finance home loan rates"},{"content":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Homestar Finance offers relatively no-frills online-only home loans, making it suitable for tech-savvy owner-occupiers, investors or refinancers. It doesn&rsquo;t offer specialist mortgages such as low-doc mortgages, high-LVR mortgages or SMSF mortgages.</span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Because it doesn&rsquo;t have to maintain costly branches and in-branch staff, Homestar Finance home loan rates tend to be very low to moderately low. </span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In terms of fees, upfront fees are typically moderately high, although ongoing fees are very low.</span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Homestar Finance&rsquo;s allowance for extra repayments, offset accounts and redraw facilities on some of its products also mean it&rsquo;s likely to be an attractive option for those who want more control over their mortgage.</span></p>\r\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Homestar Finance home loans can be principal and interest or interest-only, while borrowers can also choose for their mortgages to be variable, fixed or split.</span></p>","order":"2","title":"Homestar Finance home loans review"}],"cons":["Limited branch network.","Limited options to contact the lender."],"count":96,"customer_service_description":"<p>Homestar Finance customers can make contact with customer support by calling the contact centre or by using the online enquiry form. As Homestar Finance is an only-only lender there is no option for face-to-face customer support. Customers can access their loan details through an online banking interface.</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Customer service centre (phone)</li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li>Online banking</li>\n</ul>","eligibility_description":"<p>Borrowers wanting to apply for a Homestar Finance home loan can either complete an online enquiry form or call through to the Contact Centre for more support. Before applying for a Homestar Finance home loan, consider what you can afford to borrow and what other costs you need to factor in. To apply for a Homestar Finance home loan, you will need to supply the following information:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Proof of identity.</li>\n<li>Proof of income and employment.</li>\n<li>Provide information about the property you&rsquo;re using as security.</li>\n<li>Provide a list of assets and liabilities.</li>\n</ul>","hasContent":true,"logo":"//production-ultimate-assets.ratecity.com.au/ratecity/image/upload/v1487125696/company/qyrz0skexcq66zmw9enf.png","metadata":{"google":{},"og":{},"textContent":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Homestar Finance was established in 2004 and has an alliance with Origin Mortgage Management Services (Origin MMS). A property investment expert has revealed suburbs around Australia that are set to gentrify.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Research by Peter Koulizos, the chairman of Property Investment Professionals of Australia (PIPA), has identified 12 suburbs in four states:</span></p>\n<div class=\"table-responsive\">\n<table class=\"table table-striped\">\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th><strong>City</strong></th>\n<th><strong>Suburb</strong></th>\n<th><strong>Postcode</strong></th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">Brisbane</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">Woolloongabba</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">4102</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Adelaide</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Thebarton</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">5031</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Adelaide</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">West Croydon</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">5008</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Adelaide</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Hindmarsh</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">5007</span></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n</div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said gentrification is continuing in capital cities across the country – the key is to buy in those locations early to make the most of the potential price upswing.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>If you had this knowledge a few decades ago, you would have bought in suburbs such as Balmain and Paddington in Sydney before they became highly sought-after and expensive,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Likewise, in Melbourne, where you would have invested in Richmond or Collingwood before they became really popular and pricey.<span>”</span></span></p>\n<p><img style=\"width: 100%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20171205132448/iStock-8276154041.jpg\" /></p>\n<h3>The four signs of gentrification</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos’ research found four key indicators when city suburbs are poised to gentrify:</span></p>\n<ol>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater decrease than the state average in people aged 18 years and under</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater increase than the state average in couples without children</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater increase than the state average in people that lived at a different address five years earlier</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater increase in the percentage of females working in professional occupations</span></li>\n</ol>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">When an inner suburb experiences an increase in childless couples and a decrease in children, it suggests younger adults are moving to areas that are close to universities and employment hubs, according to Mr Koulizos.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>They can&#8217;t afford to live in the ritzy eastern suburbs of Sydney, Melbourne or Adelaide, so they target the more affordable and gentrifying inner-western suburbs of these cities,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said another indicator of gentrification is when older long-term residents are replaced by younger new arrivals. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>It is often the case that before an area gentrifies it is full of older people who are still living in the houses they bought 50 years ago. As many of them are now on fixed incomes or pensions, they can&#8217;t afford to make substantial improvements to their homes, so in move the younger people,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Many of them work in professional jobs in the city, on relatively high incomes, no dependants and have a high disposable income and <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/how-much-can-i-borrow\">borrowing capacity</a>, so they have the ability to upgrade the period and character homes.<span>”</span></span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said the final sign of gentrification is an increase in the numbers of white-collar women, who have the funds to buy, renovate, upgrade or develop homes in the area.</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Small-deposit mortgages now harder to get</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Banks tighten the screws on home loans</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/banks-tighten-screws-small-deposit-mortgages\">Read More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>","category":["property","property investment","real estate"],"coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Nick Bendel","compliedAuthor":"39","content:encoded":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Looking to invest in the next Balmain or Collingwood? A property investment expert has revealed suburbs around Australia that are set to gentrify.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Research by Peter Koulizos, the chairman of Property #0000ff;\">Brisbane</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">Annerley</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">4103</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">Brisbane</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">Lutwyche</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">4030</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">Brisbane</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">Woolloongabba</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">4102</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Adelaide</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Thebarton</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">5031</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Adelaide</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">West Croydon</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">5008</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Adelaide</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Hindmarsh</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">5007</span></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n</div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said gentrification is continuing in capital cities across the country – the key is to buy in those locations early to make the most of the potential price upswing.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>If you had this knowledge a few decades ago, you would have bought in suburbs such as Balmain and Paddington in Sydney before they became highly sought-after and expensive,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Likewise, in Melbourne, where you would have invested in Richmond or Collingwood before they became really popular and pricey.<span>”</span></span></p>\n<p><img style=\"width: 100%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20171205132448/iStock-8276154041.jpg\" /></p>\n<h3>The four signs of gentrification</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos’ research found four key indicators when city suburbs are poised to gentrify:</span></p>\n<ol>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater decrease than the state average in people aged 18 years and under</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater increase than the state average in couples without children</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater increase than the state average in people that lived at a different address five years earlier</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater increase in the percentage of females working in professional occupations</span></li>\n</ol>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">When an inner suburb experiences an increase in childless couples and a decrease in children, it suggests younger adults are moving to areas that are close to universities and employment hubs, according to Mr Koulizos.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>They can&#8217;t afford to live in the ritzy eastern suburbs of Sydney, Melbourne or Adelaide, so they target the more affordable and gentrifying inner-western suburbs of these cities,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said another indicator of gentrification is when older long-term residents are replaced by younger new arrivals. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>It is often the case that before an area gentrifies it is full of older people who are still living in the houses they bought 50 years ago. As many of them are now on fixed incomes or pensions, they can&#8217;t afford to make substantial improvements to their homes, so in move the younger people,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Many of them work in professional jobs in the city, on relatively high incomes, no dependants and have a high disposable income and <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/how-much-can-i-borrow\">borrowing capacity</a>, so they have the ability to upgrade the period and character homes.<span>”</span></span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said the final sign of gentrification is an increase in the numbers of white-collar women, who have the funds to buy, renovate, upgrade or develop homes in the area.</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Small-deposit mortgages now harder to get</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Banks tighten the screws on home loans</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/banks-tighten-screws-small-deposit-mortgages\">Read More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>","created_at":"1529719833","dc:creator":"Nick Bendel","description":"Looking to invest in the next Balmain or Collingwood? week also shows banks are limiting the number of low deposit products on the market. Bristow","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span>If you never remember to deposit money into your savings account, but always remember to Instagram your food, grab your fitbit before walking the dog, or check in your location when you&#8217;re out and about, there may be an app that can help you insert savings into your regular routine, thanks to ING and IFTTT (If This, Then That). </span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>The fintech feature will allow ING customers to link their everyday apps with their transaction and savings accounts, and to set rules for automatically transferring funds between these accounts when app activity occurs. </span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>According to ING, this “set-and-forget” system could be used to:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><span>Put $20 towards a tropical holiday every time the temperature drops below 19 degrees</span></li>\n<li><span>Put $5 towards a new pair of runners every time a daily step or exercise goal is reached</span></li>\n<li><span>Make chores rewarding; put away $1 every time one is completed</span></li>\n<li><span>Put $5 towards your savings every time your favourite celebrity tweets</span> </li>\n</ul>\n<p><span>According to IFTTT CEO, Linden Tibbets, ING customers with an Orange Everyday Account that’s linked to a Savings Maximiser account will be able to connect their everyday banking to 600 apps and devices, and set their own triggers for transferring money to their savings accounts. .</span></p>\n<p><span>ING head of digital and innovation, Chris Barwick, said that the incidental savings for customers from this collaboration with IFTTT “can really add up.”</span></p>\n<blockquote><p><span>“While there’s no denying that saving makes you feel good, setting up a savings plan can sometimes feel like a chore. This collaboration with IFTTT is designed to make saving fun and help our customers get ahead with ease.”</span></p>\n<p><span>“This partnership opens up new possibilities for our customers to save; it means they can save almost whenever, wherever and however they want.”</span></p>\n</blockquote>","category":["fintech","ifttt","ing","ing australia","savings accounts"],"coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/e836e1529b0c8683706ac90e06831a2a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Mark Bristow","compliedAuthor":"55","content:encoded":"<p><span>If you never remember to deposit money into your savings account, but always remember to Instagram your food, grab your fitbit before walking the dog, or check in your location when you&#8217;re out and about, there may be an app that can help you insert savings into your regular routine, thanks to ING and IFTTT (If This, Then That). </span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>The fintech feature will allow ING customers to link their everyday apps with their transaction and savings accounts, and to set rules for automatically transferring funds between these accounts when app activity occurs. </span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>According to ING, this “set-and-forget” system could be used to:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><span>Put $20 towards a tropical holiday every time the temperature drops below 19 degrees</span></li>\n<li><span>Put $5 towards a new pair of runners every time a daily step or exercise goal is reached</span></li>\n<li><span>Make chores rewarding; Federal Court has today approved an agreement between Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA) and AUSTRAC, resolving the civil proceedings commenced by AUSTRAC in August 2017.","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"bank-accounts","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Alex Ritchie","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>The Federal Court has today approved an agreement between <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Commonwealth Bank</a> of Australia (CBA) and AUSTRAC, resolving the civil proceedings commenced by AUSTRAC in August 2017.</p>\n<p>With the Federal Court’s approval, this has become the largest ever civil penalty in Australian corporate history.</p>\n<p>CBA will “recognise a $700 million expense in its financial statements for the full year ending 30 June 2018, which will be released on 8 August 2018”, according to a <span><a href=\"https://www.commbank.com.au/guidance/newsroom/austrac-settlement-approved-201806.html\">statement</a></span> released today.</p>\n<p>Earlier in June, AUSTRAC stated that CBA had accepted that:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>“It failed to carry out an appropriate assessment of the money laundering and terrorism financing (ML/TF) risks of its IDMs[intelligent deposit machines] prior to October 2017;</li>\n<li>It failed to complete the introduction of appropriate controls to mitigate and manage the ML/TF risks of IDMs prior to April 2018;</li>\n<li>It failed to provide 53,506 threshold transaction reports to AUSTRAC on time for cash transactions of $10,000 or more through IDMs from November 2012 to September 2015, having a total value of about $625 million;</li>\n<li>For a period of three years, it did not comply with the requirements of its AML/CTF program relating to monitoring transactions on 778,370 accounts;</li>\n<li>It failed to report suspicious matters on time, or at all, involving transactions in the tens of millions of dollars; and</li>\n<li>Even after it became aware of suspected money laundering or structuring on CBA accounts, it did not monitor its customers to mitigate and manage ML/TF risk, including the ongoing ML/TF risks of doing business with those customers.”</li>\n</ul>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">CBA agrees to pay $700m penalty</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Money laundering, terrorism funding and more</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg active\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/bank-accounts/news/cba-agrees-700m-penalty\">Learn more now</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>","category":["CBA","Commonwealth Bank"],"coauthor_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Alex Ritchie","compliedAuthor":"55","content:encoded":"<p>The Federal Court has today approved an agreement between <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Commonwealth Bank</a> of Australia (CBA) and AUSTRAC, resolving the civil proceedings commenced by AUSTRAC in August 2017.</p>\n<p>With the Federal Court’s approval, this has become the largest ever civil penalty in Australian corporate history.</p>\n<p>CBA will “recognise a $700 million expense in its financial statements for the full year ending 30 June 2018, which will be released on 8 August 2018”, according to a <span><a href=\"https://www.commbank.com.au/guidance/newsroom/austrac-settlement-approved-201806.html\">statement</a></span> released today.</p>\n<p>Earlier in June, AUSTRAC stated that CBA had accepted that:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>“It failed to carry out an appropriate assessment of the money laundering and terrorism financing (ML/TF) risks of its IDMs[intelligent deposit machines] prior to October 2017;</li>\n<li>It failed to complete the introduction of appropriate controls to mitigate and manage the ML/TF risks of IDMs prior to April 2018;</li>\n<li>It failed to provide 53,506 threshold transaction reports to AUSTRAC on time for cash transactions of $10,000 or more through IDMs from November 2012 to September 2015, having a total value of about $625 million;</li>\n<li>For a period of three years, it did not comply with the requirements of its AML/CTF program relating to monitoring transactions on 778,370 accounts;</li>\n<li>It failed to report suspicious matters on time, or at all, involving transactions in the tens of millions of dollars; and</li>\n<li>Even after it became aware of suspected money laundering or structuring on CBA accounts, it did not monitor its customers to mitigate and manage ML/TF risk, including the ongoing ML/TF risks of doing business with those customers.”</li>\n</ul>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 now","type":"article","updated_at":"1529414461","url":"/home-loans/mortgage-news/rba-sees-no-reason-lift-rates-right-now","uses_markdown":"false"},{"SEO_Smart_Links":"[null,null,\"\",\"\",null]","_edit_last":"55","_edit_lock":"1529288549:55","_yoast_wpseo_metadesc":"New research from RateCity shows banks have put the brakes on lending to people with small deposits, slashing the number of mortgage products with a maximum loan-to-value ratio (LVR) of 95 per cent in the past three years. Fewer than a third (32 per cent) of home loans in the RateCity database now offer lending up to a maximum of 95 per cent of the value of the property.","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"home-loans","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Nick Bendel","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>New research from <a href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans\">RateCity</a> shows banks have put the brakes on lending to people with small deposits, slashing the number of mortgage products with a maximum loan-to-value ratio (LVR) of 95 per cent in the past three years.</p>\n<p>Fewer than a third (32 per cent) of home loans in the RateCity database now offer lending up to a maximum of 95 per cent of the value of the property.</p>\n<p>That’s down from 76 per cent of all loans on offer in early 2015, in line with lending guidelines by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, who want loans with small deposits to be the exception, rather than the rule.</p>\n<p>Sally Tindall, spokesperson at RateCity, said the banks were actively looking for deposits of 20 per cent, if not more.</p>\n<p>“For Australians battling to crack into the highly competitive home loan market, low-deposit loans have been a doorway in. But the rules have changed and now borrowers that might have been given the green light three years ago are starting to be turned away,” she said.</p>\n<p>RateCity research shows that upgrading from a 5 per cent deposit to a 20 per cent deposit on a $500,000 mortgage will require a buyer to stump up an extra $75,000 in cash.</p>\n<p>“These new LVR requirements will set a lot of potential buyers back, because they just don’t have access to that kind of money,&#8221; Ms Tindall said.</p>\n<p>“But the alternative is worse. Stretching yourself thin at record-low interest rates can be a recipe for disaster.</p>\n<p>“It’s been over seven years since we’ve experienced an <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\">RBA rate</a> hike and people have become complacent. These new LVR rules will sharpen the focus of those who are serious about securing housing finance.&#8221;</p>","category":["mortgage","mortgages"],"coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Nick Bendel","compliedAuthor":"18","content:encoded":"<p>New research from <a href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans\">RateCity</a> shows banks have put the brakes on lending to people with small deposits, slashing the number of mortgage products with a maximum loan-to-value ratio (LVR) of 95 per cent in the past three years.</p>\n<p>Fewer than a third (32 per cent) of home loans in the RateCity database now offer lending up to a maximum of 95 per cent of the value of the property.</p>\n<p>That’s down from 76 per cent of all loans on offer in early 2015, in line with lending guidelines by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, who want loans with small deposits to be the exception, rather than the rule.</p>\n<p>Sally Tindall, spokesperson at RateCity, said the banks were actively looking for deposits of 20 per cent, if not more.</p>\n<p>“For Australians battling to crack into the highly competitive home loan market, low-deposit loans have been a doorway in. But the rules have changed and now borrowers that might have been given the green light three years ago are starting to be turned away,” she said.</p>\n<p>RateCity research shows that upgrading from a 5 per cent deposit to a 20 per cent deposit on a $500,000 mortgage will require a buyer to stump up an extra $75,000 in cash.</p>\n<p>“These new LVR requirements will set a lot of potential buyers back, because they just don’t have access to that kind of money,&#8221; Ms Tindall said.</p>\n<p>“But the alternative is worse. Stretching yourself thin at record-low interest rates can be a recipe for disaster.</p>\n<p>“It’s been over seven years since we’ve experienced an <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\">RBA rate</a> hike and people have become complacent. peak real estate body.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The Real Estate Institute of Australia (REIA) has applied to the Professional Standards Authority for admission as a profession, with the process expected to be completed by the end of 2019.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">If the REIA proposal is accepted, participating real estate agents will have to:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Pass “rigorous tests” to become recognised as a ‘professional’ real estate agent</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Adhere to a code of ethics (and associated “auditable accountability commitments”)</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Meet ongoing training standards</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Real estate agents would no longer be recognised as ‘professional’ agents if they failed to maintain their commitment to ethics and training.</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Some go up, others go down</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Westpac changes its fixed-rate mortgages</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/westpac-changes-fixed-rate-mortgages\">Read more</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">REIA president Malcolm Gunning said in the future there would be two types of real estate agent &#8211; those who were members of the professional scheme and those who were outside the scheme.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“This scheme will not be for all agents, as only those prepared to raise the bar on their own standards, skills, education, performance and commitments will qualify,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“For those agents wishing to pursue a professional path, education and training standards will be raised far beyond those currently required for regulatory purposes, which will result in significant consumer benefits.”</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Rates fall by up to 26 400;\">Real estate agents will have to commit to higher training standards and a new code of ethics, under a proposal by Australia’s peak real estate body.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The Real Estate Institute of Australia (REIA) has applied to the Professional Standards Authority for admission as a profession, with the process expected to be completed by the end of 2019.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">If the REIA proposal is accepted, participating real estate agents will have to:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span code of ethics (and associated “auditable accountability commitments”)</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Meet ongoing training standards</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Real estate agents would no longer be recognised as ‘professional’ agents if they failed to maintain their commitment to ethics and training.</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Some go up, others go down</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Westpac changes its fixed-rate mortgages</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/westpac-changes-fixed-rate-mortgages\">Read more</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">REIA president Malcolm Gunning said in the future there would be two types of real estate agent &#8211; those who were members of the professional scheme and those who were outside the scheme.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“This scheme will not be for all agents, as only those prepared to raise the bar on their own standards, skills, education, performance and commitments will qualify,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“For those agents wishing to pursue a professional path, education and training standards will be raised far beyond those currently required for regulatory purposes, which will result in significant consumer benefits.”</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Rates fall by up to 26 </span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>The fintech feature will allow ING customers to link their everyday apps with their transaction and savings accounts, and to set rules for automatically transferring funds between these accounts when app activity occurs. </span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>According to ING, this “set-and-forget” system could be used to:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><span>Put $20 towards a tropical holiday every time the temperature drops below 19 degrees</span></li>\n<li><span>Put $5 towards a new pair of runners every time a daily step or exercise goal is tweets</span> </li>\n</ul>\n<p><span>According to IFTTT CEO, Linden Tibbets, ING customers with an Orange Everyday Account that’s linked to a Savings Maximiser account will be able to connect their everyday banking to 600 apps and devices, and set their own triggers for transferring money to their savings accounts. .</span></p>\n<p><span>ING head of digital and innovation, Chris Barwick, said that the incidental savings for customers from this collaboration with IFTTT “can really add up.”</span></p>\n<blockquote><p><span>“While there’s no denying that saving makes you feel good, setting up a savings plan can sometimes feel like a chore. This collaboration with IFTTT is designed to make saving fun and help our customers get ahead with ease.”</span></p>\n<p><span>“This partnership opens up new possibilities for our customers to save; it means they can save almost whenever, wherever and however they want.”</span></p>\n</blockquote>","category":["fintech","ifttt","ing","ing australia","savings accounts"],"coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/e836e1529b0c8683706ac90e06831a2a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Mark Bristow","compliedAuthor":"55","content:encoded":"<p><span>If you never remember to deposit money into your savings account, but always remember to Instagram your food, grab your fitbit before walking the dog, or check in your location when you&#8217;re out and about, there may be an app that can help you insert savings into your regular routine, thanks to ING and IFTTT (If This, Then That). </span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>The fintech feature will allow ING customers to link their everyday apps with their transaction and savings accounts, and to set rules for automatically transferring funds between these accounts when app activity occurs. </span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>According to ING, this “set-and-forget” system could be used to:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><span>Put $20 towards a tropical holiday every time the temperature drops below 19 degrees</span></li>\n<li><span>Put $5 towards a new pair of runners every time a daily step or exercise goal is reached</span></li>\n<li><span>Make chores rewarding;
