Ritchie","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>The Federal Court has today approved an agreement between <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Commonwealth Bank</a> of Australia (CBA) and AUSTRAC, resolving the civil proceedings commenced by AUSTRAC in August 2017.</p>\n<p>With the Federal Court’s approval, this has become the largest ever civil penalty in Australian corporate history.</p>\n<p>CBA will “recognise a $700 million expense in its financial statements for the full year ending 30 June 2018, which will be released on 8 August 2018”, according to a <span><a href=\"https://www.commbank.com.au/guidance/newsroom/austrac-settlement-approved-201806.html\">statement</a></span> released today.</p>\n<p>Earlier in June, AUSTRAC stated that CBA had accepted that:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>“It failed to carry out an appropriate assessment of the money laundering and terrorism financing (ML/TF) risks of its IDMs[intelligent deposit machines] prior to October 2017;</li>\n<li>It failed to complete the introduction of appropriate controls to mitigate and manage the ML/TF risks of IDMs prior to April 2018;</li>\n<li>It failed to provide 53,506 threshold transaction reports to AUSTRAC on time for cash transactions of $10,000 or more through IDMs from November 2012 to September 2015, having a total value of about $625 million;</li>\n<li>For a period of three years, it did not comply with the requirements of its AML/CTF program relating to monitoring transactions on 778,370 accounts;</li>\n<li>It failed to report suspicious matters on time, or at all, involving transactions in the tens of millions of dollars; and</li>\n<li>Even after it became aware of suspected money laundering or structuring on CBA accounts, it did not monitor its customers to mitigate and manage ML/TF risk, including the ongoing ML/TF risks of doing business with those customers.”</li>\n</ul>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">CBA agrees to pay $700m penalty</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Money laundering, civil proceedings commenced by AUSTRAC in August 2017.</p>\n<p>With the Federal Court’s approval, this has become the largest ever civil penalty in Australian corporate history.</p>\n<p>CBA will “recognise a $700 million expense in its financial statements for the full year ending 30 June 2018, which will be released on 8 August 2018”, according to a <span><a href=\"https://www.commbank.com.au/guidance/newsroom/austrac-settlement-approved-201806.html\">statement</a></span> released today.</p>\n<p>Earlier in June, AUSTRAC stated that CBA had accepted that:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>“It failed to carry out an appropriate assessment of the money laundering and terrorism financing (ML/TF) risks of its IDMs[intelligent deposit machines] prior to October 2017;</li>\n<li>It failed to complete the introduction of appropriate controls to mitigate and manage the ML/TF risks of IDMs prior to April 2018;</li>\n<li>It failed to provide 53,506 threshold transaction reports to AUSTRAC on time for cash transactions of $10,000 or more through IDMs from November 2012 to September 2015, having a total value of about $625 million;</li>\n<li>For a period of three years, it did not comply with the requirements of its AML/CTF program relating to monitoring transactions on 778,370 accounts;</li>\n<li>It failed to report suspicious matters on time, or at all, involving transactions in the tens of millions of dollars; and</li>\n<li>Even after it became aware of suspected money laundering or structuring on CBA accounts, it did not monitor its customers CBA will “recognise a $700 million expense in its financial statements for &#8230; <a href=\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/federal-court-approves-cba-pay-largest-ever-civil-penalty-history/\" class=\"more-link\">Continue reading<span class=\"screen-reader-text\"> \"Federal Court approves: CBA to pay largest ever civil penalty in history\"</span></a>","exclusive_to_partner":"false","faq_description":null,"guid":{"$t":"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=76957","isPermaLink":"false"},"has_video":"false","header_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180620161801/iStock-473211628-1-1024x790.jpg","id":76957,"link":"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/federal-court-approves-cba-pay-largest-ever-civil-penalty-history/","media_release":null,"overallRating":null,"page_header":null,"page_subheader":null,"partner_name":null,"post_id":"76957","pubDate":"Wed, 20 Jun 2018 06:26:42 +0000","publish_until":null,"question":null,"quote":null,"readingTime":2,"result_name":null,"short_description":"With the Federal Court’s approval, this has become the largest ever civil penalty in Australian corporate history.","slider_data":[],"slug":"federal-court-approves-cba-pay-largest-ever-civil-penalty-history","status":"publish","supplierReference":null,"supplier_reference":null,"thumbnail_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180620161801/iStock-473211628-1-350x500.jpg","title":"Federal Court approves: CBA to pay largest ever civil penalty in history","type":"article","updated_at":"1529512002","url":"/bank-accounts/news/federal-court-approves-cba-pay-largest-ever-civil-penalty-history","uses_markdown":"false"},{"SEO_Smart_Links":"[null,null,\"\",\"\",null]","_edit_last":"55","_edit_lock":"1528952470:55","_yoast_wpseo_metadesc":"As tax time approaches, the Australian Taxation Office has warned that it will pay close attention to claims for work-related clothing and laundry expenses. Clothing and laundry claims have risen by about 20 per cent over the last five years, according to the ATO.","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"bank-accounts","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Nick Bendel","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">As tax time approaches, the Australian Taxation Office has warned that it will pay close attention to claims for work-related clothing and laundry expenses.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Clothing and laundry claims have risen by about 20 per cent over the last five years, according to the ATO.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">There are now about 6.3 million people claiming about $1.8 billion in clothing and laundry expenses. Almost half of all taxpayers now claim deductions for work-related clothing.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ATO assistant commissioner Kath Anderson said taxpayers can legitimately claim work-related clothing and laundry only if it meets one of these three conditions:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">It&#8217;s unique and distinct to their employer</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>It&#8217;s p</span>rotective (such as high-vis vests, steel-capped boots, overalls or aprons)</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>It&#8217;s o</span>ccupation-specific (such as a chef’s checkered pants)</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“But you can’t claim everyday items you wear that might offer you some protection – like closed-in shoes. A uniform clearly identifies you as being part of a particular organisation. Now we know the rules are tricky, so if you’re not sure make sure, you check out our <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.ato.gov.au/Individuals/Income-and-deductions/Deductions-you-can-claim/\">website</a>.”</span></p>\n<p><img style=\"width: 100%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180614103743/High-viz-vests-e1528936718969.jpg\" /></p>\n<h3>You can’t make a claim for normal work clothes</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ms Anderson said the most common mistake the ATO sees is Australians claiming normal clothes that they happen to wear to work, like a suit or black pants.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Some people think they can claim normal clothes because their boss told them to wear a particular colour or there is a certain dress code in their workplace,” she said. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Or in the case of some retailers, employees are actually required to wear items from the latest line.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Others think they can claim normal clothes because they only ever wear those clothes to work. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“However, all of those people are wrong. You simply can’t claim a tax deduction for normal clothing that you wear to work, even if your boss told you to wear it or you only wear it to work.”</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">But big gap remains&#8230;</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Gender salary gap narrows</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/news/gender-salary-gap-narrows-remains-large\">Read More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h3>There is no automatic $150 laundry entitlement</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ms Anderson also said a lot of Australians falsely believe anyone can make a $150 laundry claim.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Last year, about 1.6 million people claimed exactly $150. For many, it’s a legitimate expense. But we know some people are incorrectly treating it as a standard entitlement, a sort of safe amount that anyone can claim,” she said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You can only claim for clothing and laundry if:</span></p>\n<ol>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You bought it yourself and weren’t reimbursed</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You were required to wear a uniform unique and distinct to your employer, or protective clothing, or occupation-specific clothing</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You’ve got a record that demonstrates how you calculated your claim</span></li>\n</ol>","category":["ATO","tax"],"coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Nick Bendel","compliedAuthor":"44","content:encoded":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">As tax time approaches, the Australian Taxation Office has warned that it will pay close attention to claims for work-related clothing and laundry expenses.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Clothing and laundry claims have risen by about 20 per cent over the last five years, according to the ATO.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">There are now about 6.3 million people claiming about $1.8 billion in clothing and laundry expenses. Almost half of all taxpayers now claim deductions for work-related clothing.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ATO assistant commissioner Kath Anderson said taxpayers can legitimately claim work-related clothing and laundry only if it meets one of these three conditions:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">It&#8217;s unique and distinct to their employer</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>It&#8217;s p</span>rotective (such as high-vis vests, steel-capped boots, overalls or aprons)</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>It&#8217;s o</span>ccupation-specific (such as a chef’s checkered pants)</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“But you can’t claim everyday items you wear that might offer you some protection – like closed-in shoes. A uniform clearly identifies you as being part of a particular organisation. Now we know the rules are tricky, so if you’re not sure make sure, you check out our <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"https://www.ato.gov.au/Individuals/Income-and-deductions/Deductions-you-can-claim/\">website</a>.”</span></p>\n<p><img style=\"width: 100%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180614103743/High-viz-vests-e1528936718969.jpg\" /></p>\n<h3>You can’t make a claim for normal work clothes</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ms Anderson said the most common mistake the ATO sees is Australians claiming normal clothes that they happen to wear to work, like a suit or black pants.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Some people think they can claim normal clothes because their boss told them to wear a particular colour or there is a certain dress code in their workplace,” she said. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Or in the case of some retailers, employees are actually required to wear items from the latest line.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Others think they can claim normal clothes because they only ever wear those clothes to work. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“However, all of those people are wrong. You simply can’t claim a tax deduction for normal clothing that you wear to work, even if your boss told you to wear it or you only wear it to work.”</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">But big gap remains&#8230;</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Gender salary gap narrows</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/savings-accounts/news/gender-salary-gap-narrows-remains-large\">Read More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h3>There is no automatic $150 laundry entitlement</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Ms Anderson also said a lot of Australians falsely believe anyone can make a $150 laundry claim.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Last year, about 1.6 million people claimed exactly $150. For many, it’s a legitimate expense. But we know some people are incorrectly treating it as a standard entitlement, a sort of safe amount that anyone can claim,” she said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You can only claim for clothing and laundry if:</span></p>\n<ol>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You bought it yourself and weren’t reimbursed</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You were required to wear a uniform unique and distinct to your employer, or protective clothing, or occupation-specific clothing</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">You’ve got a record that demonstrates how you calculated your claim</span></li>\n</ol>","created_at":"1529117026","dc:creator":"Nick Bendel","description":"As tax time approaches, the Australian Taxation Office has warned that it will pay close attention to claims for work-related clothing and laundry expenses. Clothing and laundry claims have risen by about 20 per cent over the last five years, according to the ATO. There are now about 6.3 million people claiming about $1.8 billion &#8230; <a href=\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/ato-busts-myths-flags-crackdown/\" class=\"more-link\">Continue reading<span class=\"screen-reader-text\"> \"ATO busts myths, flags crackdown\"</span></a>","exclusive_to_partner":"false","faq_description":null,"guid":{"$t":"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=76736","isPermaLink":"false"},"has_video":"false","header_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180614103745/Myths-facts-750x420.jpg","id":76736,"link":"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/ato-busts-myths-flags-crackdown/","media_release":null,"overallRating":null,"page_header":null,"page_subheader":null,"partner_name":null,"post_id":"76736","pubDate":"Fri, 15 Jun 2018 16:43:46 +0000","publish_until":null,"question":null,"quote":null,"readingTime":3,"result_name":null,"short_description":"As tax time approaches, the Australian Taxation Office has warned that it will pay close attention to claims for work-related clothing and laundry expenses.","slider_data":[],"slug":"ato-busts-myths-flags-crackdown","status":"publish","supplierReference":null,"supplier_reference":null,"thumbnail_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180614103745/Myths-facts-350x500.jpg","title":"ATO busts myths, flags crackdown","type":"article","updated_at":"1528988611","url":"/bank-accounts/news/ato-busts-myths-flags-crackdown","uses_markdown":"false"},{"SEO_Smart_Links":"[null,null,\"\",\"\",null]","_edit_last":"55","_edit_lock":"1529025233:55","_yoast_wpseo_metadesc":"Moody’s has affirmed Australia’s AAA credit rating, although it has also warned of “two key vulnerabilities” to the economy. Moody’s gave four main reasons for Australia’s strong credit rating","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"savings-accounts","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Nick Bendel","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Moody’s has affirmed Australia’s AAA credit rating, although it has also warned of “two key vulnerabilities” to the economy.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Moody’s gave four main reasons for Australia’s strong credit rating:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Robust and stable GDP growth</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Very high resilience to economic shocks</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Moderate government debt</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Strong institutions that preserve macroeconomic and financial stability</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The ratings agency also said that it expects Australia to retain its AAA credit rating for the foreseeable future. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Moody’s said that “even in the event of shocks, possibly in the housing market and/or to the economy&#8217;s access to external financing, the resilience of the economy supported by countercyclical macroeconomic policy” would allow Australia to retain its strong credit profile.</span></p>\n<div class=\"breakout breakout-tip\">\n<div class=\"breakout-heading\">\n<p class=\"breakout-title\">Australia &#8211; key economic stats</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"breakout-body\">\n<ul>\n<li>Economic growth = 3.1%</li>\n<li><span>Unemployment rate = 5.4%</span></li>\n<li><span>Inflation rate = 1.9%</span></li>\n<li><span>Average weekly earnings = $1,567.90</span></li>\n<li>Household debt-to-income ratio = 188.6%</li>\n</ul>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h3>RBA and APRA get big tick</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Moody’s paid tribute to the Reserve Bank’s handling of monetary policy, which it described as “a key aspect of Australia&#8217;s institutional strength”.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“The Reserve Bank of Australia maintains stable inflation at moderate positive rates. In addition, the central bank has preserved capacity to use conventional monetary policy to offset shocks, should they occur,” according to Moody’s.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Moody’s also spoke positively about how APRA, the banking regulator, had managed the banking system.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Australia ranks particularly highly in the Worldwide Governance Indicators on regulatory quality, which corroborates Moody&#8217;s assessment of the quality of regulation of the financial sector,” it said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“For example, in recently responding to rising risks of a potential housing market downturn, [APRA] implemented restrictions on excessive lending to property investors, in order to curb debt-fuelled property demand. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">&#8220;APRA also raised bank capital requirements in response to the Financial System Inquiry&#8217;s recommendation to further enhance the strength and resilience of the banking system.”</span></p>\n<div class=\"breakout breakout-tip\">\n<div class=\"breakout-heading\">\n<p class=\"breakout-title\">Government reaction</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"breakout-body\">\n<p>Treasurer Scott Morrison welcomed Moody&#8217;s decision to affirm Australia&#8217;s AAA credit rating. &#8220;<span>The government&#8217;s record of strong economic management has ensured Australia&#8217;s AAA credit rating has been maintained with all three major ratings agencies, one of just 10 countries to have achieved this,&#8221; he said.</span></p>\n<p>&#8220;<span>The Turnbull government is sticking to our plan for a stronger economy to guarantee the essential services Australians rely on and create more Australian jobs, while ensuring the government lives within its means by bringing the budget back into balance.&#8221;</span></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h3>Moody’s concerned about household debt</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Despite giving Australia a largely upbeat assessment, Moody’s also highlighted “two key vulnerabilities”.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“One is high and rising household debt, which exposes the economy, and consequently public finances, to any house price downturn,” it said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“The second is its longstanding dependence on overseas financing, which leaves it subject to changes in investor sentiment towards Australian assets.”</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Financial stress widespread</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">One in three Australians on loans.</p>\n<p>These findings come from <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\">Westpac</a>’s 2018 Financial Literacy Study and show the degree to finances and make sound economic decisions.</p>\n<p>The <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\">Westpac</a> study also found that young Australians aren’t the only ones worried about their financial futures.</p>\n<p>Research showed that 74 per cent of parents fear their children don’t have enough financial knowledge to make sound economic choices as they transition into life after school, and over half of parents do not feel very confident answering when their children ask for financial advice.</p>\n<p>To help ease the pressure of financial decision-making and increase financial literacy in young Australians, <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\">Westpac</a> has teamed up with Year13 – an online platform for school leavers – to help adolescent Aussies improve their financial literacy.</p>\n<p>The program, called ‘FinLit,’ contains free online resources that will help young Australians navigate their financial future as they leave school. young Australians worry they are making poor financial choices.","slider_data":[],"slug":"young-aussies-lack-financial-confidence","status":"publish","supplierReference":null,"supplier_reference":null,"thumbnail_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180606142140/Student-with-money-350x500.jpg","title":"Young Aussies lack financial confidence","type":"article","updated_at":"1528364049","url":"/savings-accounts/news/young-aussies-lack-financial-confidence","uses_markdown":"false"},{"SEO_Smart_Links":"[null,null,\"\",\"\",null]","_edit_last":"44","_edit_lock":"1528078113:44","_yoast_wpseo_metadesc":"CBA have come to an agreement with AUSTRAC to pay a $700 million penalty relating to serious breaches of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing laws.","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"bank-accounts","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Alex Ritchie","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Commonwealth Bank</a> have come to an agreement with AUSTRAC to pay a $700 million penalty relating to serious breaches of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing laws.</p>\n<p>In August 2017, it was reported that Commonwealth Bank (CBA) had been in breach of more than <span><a href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/cba-faces-legal-action-money-laundering-breaches\">53,000 financial violations.</a></span></p>\n<p>Both CBA and AUSTRAC will approach the Federal Court seeking orders to this effect, and if agreed upon, this will be the largest ever civil penalty in Australian corporate history.</p>\n<p>In a statement released today, AUSTRAC said that CBA had accepted that:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>“It failed to carry out an appropriate assessment of the money laundering and terrorism financing (ML/TF) risks of its IDMs[intelligent deposit machines] prior to October 2017;</li>\n<li>It failed to complete the introduction of appropriate controls to mitigate and manage the ML/TF risks of IDMs prior to April 2018;</li>\n<li>It failed to provide 53,506 threshold transaction reports to AUSTRAC on time for cash transactions of $10,000 or more through IDMs from November 2012 to September 2015, having a total value of about $625 million;</li>\n<li>For a period of three years, it did not comply with the requirements of its AML/CTF program relating to monitoring transactions on 778,370 accounts;</li>\n<li>It failed to report suspicious matters on time, or at all, involving transactions in the tens of millions of dollars; and</li>\n<li>Even after it became aware of suspected money laundering or structuring on CBA accounts, it did not monitor its customers to mitigate and manage ML/TF risk, including the ongoing ML/TF risks of doing business with those customers.”</li>\n</ul>\n<p>AUSTRAC’s CEO, Nicole Rose, said this outcome “sends a strong message to industry that serious non-compliance with the AML/CTF Act will not be tolerated”.</p>\n<p>“As we have seen in this case, criminals will exploit poor business practices to launder the proceeds of their crimes.</p>\n<p>“This has real impacts on the everyday lives of Australians and puts the community at risk by increasing opportunities for terrorists to support attacks here and overseas, and enabling organised crime groups to peddle drugs to our families and friends.</p>\n<p>“We know that businesses are the first line of defence in protecting the community and our financial system from criminal abuse, and it is critical for AML/CTF compliance and risk management to be embedded in business strategy and practices.</p>\n<p>“I hope this result alerts the financial sector to the consequences of poor compliance, and reinforces that businesses need to take their obligations seriously,” said Ms Rose.</p>","category":["CBA","Commonwealth Bank"],"coauthor_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Alex Ritchie","compliedAuthor":"55","content:encoded":"<p><a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Commonwealth Bank</a> have come to an agreement with AUSTRAC to pay a $700 million penalty relating to serious breaches of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing laws.</p>\n<p>In August 2017, it was reported that Commonwealth Bank (CBA) had been in breach of more than <span><a href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/cba-faces-legal-action-money-laundering-breaches\">53,000 financial violations.</a></span></p>\n<p>Both CBA and AUSTRAC will approach the Federal Court seeking orders to this effect, and if agreed upon, this will be the largest ever civil penalty in Australian corporate history.</p>\n<p>In a statement released today, AUSTRAC said that CBA had accepted that:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>“It failed to carry out an appropriate assessment of the money laundering and terrorism financing (ML/TF) risks of its IDMs[intelligent deposit machines] prior to October 2017;</li>\n<li>It failed to complete the introduction of appropriate controls to mitigate and manage the ML/TF risks of IDMs prior to April 2018;</li>\n<li>It failed to provide 53,506 threshold transaction reports to AUSTRAC on time for cash transactions of $10,000 or more through IDMs from November 2012 to September 2015, having a total value of about $625 million;</li>\n<li>For a period of three years, it did not comply with the requirements of its AML/CTF program relating to monitoring transactions on 778,370 accounts;</li>\n<li>It failed to report suspicious matters on time, or at all, involving transactions in the tens of millions of dollars; and</li>\n<li>Even after it became aware of suspected money laundering or structuring on CBA accounts, it did not monitor its customers to mitigate and manage ML/TF risk, including the ongoing ML/TF risks of doing business with those customers.”</li>\n</ul>\n<p>AUSTRAC’s CEO, Nicole Rose, said this outcome “sends a strong message to industry that serious non-compliance with the AML/CTF Act will not be tolerated”.</p>\n<p>“As we have seen in this case, criminals will exploit poor business practices to launder the proceeds of their crimes.</p>\n<p>“This has real impacts on the everyday lives of Australians and puts the community at risk by increasing opportunities for terrorists to support attacks here and overseas, and enabling organised crime groups to peddle drugs to our families and friends.</p>\n<p>“We know that businesses are the first line of defence in protecting the community and our financial system from criminal abuse, and it is critical for AML/CTF compliance and risk management to be embedded in business strategy and practices.</p>\n<p>“I hope this result alerts the financial sector to the consequences of poor compliance, and reinforces that businesses need to take their obligations seriously,” said Ms Rose.</p>","created_at":"1528114112","dc:creator":"Alex Ritchie","description":"Commonwealth Bank have come to an agreement with AUSTRAC to pay a $700 million penalty relating to serious breaches of anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing laws. Ritchie","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>2.28 million Australians intend to purchase a new vehicle in the next four years, however, this number has fallen by 270,000 people from 2.55 million last year.</p>\n<p>According to Roy Morgan research for February 2018, intent to buy a new vehicle in the next 12 months has also dropped below 600,000 “for the first time in over a year”.</p>\n<h3><strong>New Vehicle Purchase Intention: February 2018</strong></h3>\n<p><img style=\"width: 100%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180502164259/7570-c1.png\" /></p>\n<p><em>Source: </em><a href=\"http://www.roymorgan.com/findings/7570-suvs-gaining-popularity-as-new-car-buying-intention-softens-201804270129\"><em>Roy Morgan Single Source Survey</em></a></p>\n<h3><strong>Which car types are the most popular?</strong></h3>\n<p>In terms of car types, Roy Morgan noted an increase in interest in SUVs, with 623,000 Australians aged 14 and over intending to buy a “new SUV/4WD, five seater within the next four years. This car type saw a dramatic increase in the intent to purchase, raising by 156,000 people from the same time last year.</p>\n<p>The next most popular car type was four door hatchbacks (483,000 people), followed by five door hatchbacks (319,000 people. However, like with intent to purchase cars in Australia, the number of people intending to buy these car types has fallen by 109,000 for a four door and 180,000 for a five door.</p>\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered table-condensed table-hover\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Car Type</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Dec 16 – Feb 17</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Dec 17 – Feb 18</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Difference</strong></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>SUV/4WD, five door, five sedan</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>592,000</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>483,000</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>-109,000</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>Five door (four side doors and a hatch back)</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>499,000</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>319,000</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>-180,000</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<p><em>Source: </em><a href=\"http://www.roymorgan.com/findings/7570-suvs-gaining-popularity-as-new-car-buying-intention-softens-201804270129\"><em>Roy Morgan Single Source Survey</em></a></p>\n<p>Norman Morris, Industry Communications Director, Roy Morgan noted that there had been “considerable growth in the new vehicle market with rising intention of purchasing a new car in the next four years, but we are now seeing a softening in the market”.</p>\n<p>“We have already seen some early signs of changes in this industry, particularly in the very rapid changes in body style preference, the move away from four and five door cars to SUVs,” said Mr Morris.</p>","category":["car loan","Roy Morgan"],"coauthor_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Alex year”.</p>\n<h3><strong>New Vehicle Purchase Intention: February 2018</strong></h3>\n<p><img style=\"width: 100%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" are the most popular?</strong></h3>\n<p>In terms of car types, Roy Morgan noted an increase in interest in SUVs, with 623,000 Australians aged 14 and over intending to buy a “new SUV/4WD, five seater within the next four years. This car type saw a dramatic increase in the intent to purchase, raising by 156,000 people from the same time last year.</p>\n<p>The next most popular car type was four door hatchbacks (483,000 people), followed by five door hatchbacks (319,000 people. However, like with intent to purchase cars in Australia, the number of people intending to buy these car types has fallen by 109,000 for a four door and 180,000 for a five door.</p>\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered table-condensed table-hover\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Car Type</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Dec 16 – Feb 17</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Dec 17 – Feb 18</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Difference</strong></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>SUV/4WD, five door, five seater</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>467,000</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>623,000</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>+156,000</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>Four door sedan</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>592,000</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>483,000</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>-109,000</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>Five door (four side doors and a hatch back)</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>499,000</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>319,000</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>-180,000</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<p><em>Source: </em><a href=\"http://www.roymorgan.com/findings/7570-suvs-gaining-popularity-as-new-car-buying-intention-softens-201804270129\"><em>Roy Morgan Single Source Survey</em></a></p>\n<p>Norman Morris, Industry Communications Director, Roy Morgan noted that there had been “considerable growth in the new vehicle market with rising intention of purchasing a new car in the next four years, but we are now seeing a softening in the market”.</p>\n<p>“We have already seen some early signs of changes in this industry, particularly in the very rapid changes in body style preference, the move away from four and five door cars to SUVs,” said Mr Morris.</p>","created_at":"1525279319","dc:creator":"Alex Ritchie","description":"2.28 million Australians intend to purchase a new vehicle in the next four years, however, this number has fallen by 270,000 people from 2.55 million last year. Bristow","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span></span><span>What’s the best way to do your research before making a new car purchase? According to new research from Roy Morgan, about two thirds of you are likely to have said “the internet” regardless of your generation. </span></p>\n<p><span>According to Roy Morgan’s Single Source Survey, 67.6% of people intending to purchase a new car in the next four years described the internet as the most useful media for providing information on their purchase decision – a difference of 10.1% on figures from 2013.</span></p>\n<p><span>Almost half (45.6%) of car buyers started their car research with an internet search engine such as Google, while around one in four (24.9%) went directly to a specific website.</span></p>\n<p><span>While all generations were found to be turning away from traditional media and towards online sources for researching new car purchases, some traditional media is remaining relevant to selected demographics:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><span>While the overall market preference for newspapers is only 10.7%, this rises to 17.7% for Baby Boomers and to 23.2% for Pre-Boomers.</span></li>\n<li><span>Television was found to be most represented among Generation Z with 8.3%, above the overall average of 5.4%. </span></li>\n<li><span>Magazines were found to only remain relevant to Pre-Boomers, with 8.8% against a market average of only 4.1%.</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span>Roy Morgan industry communications director, Norman Morris, said:</span></p>\n<blockquote><p><span>“The widespread use of the internet to provide detailed information to intending car buyers gives them unprecedented ability to make well informed decisions, particularly when negotiating with dealers.”</span></p>\n</blockquote>\n<h3>Media most useful for providing information when purchasing a new motor vehicle</h3>\n<div According to new research from Roy Morgan, about two thirds of you are likely to have said “the internet” regardless of your generation.","slider_data":[],"slug":"aussies-researching-new-cars-car-loan-rates-online","status":"publish","supplierReference":null,"supplier_reference":null,"thumbnail_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180403105758/online-car-research-350x500.jpg","title":"More Aussies researching new cars and car loan rates online","type":"article","updated_at":"1522753464","url":"/car-loans/news/aussies-researching-new-cars-car-loan-rates-online","uses_markdown":"false"},{"SEO_Smart_Links":"[null,null,\"\",\"\",null]","_edit_last":"39","_edit_lock":"1521419187:55","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"car-loans","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/e836e1529b0c8683706ac90e06831a2a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Mark Bristow","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span></span><span>More Australians have made plans to buy a new car this year, according to Roy Morgan. But as well as considering the costs of car loans and financing for their new vehicles a growing number of Aussies are also considering vehicles with alternative fuel supplies.</span><span> </span></p>\n<h3>More new car purchases forecast for 2018</h3>\n<p><span>The results of the Roy Morgan Single Source Survey show that as of December 2017, the number of Australians intending to buy a new vehicle in the next 12 months grew by 44,000 to 614,000 – a 7.7% increase on the results from the same time last year. </span></p>\n<p><span>Looking at the longer term, Australian car buying intentions over the next four years were found to have dropped by 2.29% to 2.26 million from the same time last year. However, with the industry experiencing record sales in 2017 (according to Roy Morgan), this could indicate a positive 2018 outlook for the industry.</span></p>\n<h3>New cars with new fuels</h3>\n<p><span>According to VFACTS data, 75.3% of new vehicles sold in Australia last year had petrol engines. According to Roy Morgan, of the 2.26 million Aussies looking to buy over the next four years, only 61.9% thought that their next vehicle will most likely have a petrol engine.</span></p>\n<div class=\"table-responsive\">\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered table-condensed table-hover\">\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th>Fuel type</th>\n<th>Sales share in 2017 (VFACTS)</th>\n<th>New car intenders over next 4 years (Roy Morgan)</th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>Petrol</td>\n<td>75.3%</td>\n<td>61.9%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Diesel</td>\n<td>24.1%</td>\n<td>29.2%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>LPG</td>\n<td>0.0%</td>\n<td>0.6%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Hybrid</td>\n<td>0.5%</td>\n<td>5.2%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Electric</td>\n<td>0.1%</td>\n<td>3.1%</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<p><small><em>Source: <a href=\"http://www.roymorgan.com/findings/7532-more-than-2-million-intend-to-purchase-a-new-vehicle-but-what-fuel-201803150007\">Roy Morgan</a></em></small></p>\n</div>\n<p><span>The primary alternative to standard petrol was diesel, with its preference level for new purchases over the next 4 years up 5.3% points to 29.2%, compared to the 2017 VFACTS sales data. Preference levels for hybrid (petrol and electric) cars was up by 4.7% points to 5.2%; fully electric cars by 3.0% points to 3.1%; and LPG-fuelled cars from 0% to 0.6%.</span></p>\n<h3>The challenge ahead</h3>\n<p><span>Roy Morgan industry communications director, Norman Morris, said that while the new vehicle market has experienced growth over the past decade, it is now facing the challenge of rapidly changing technologies and fuel preferences:</span></p>\n<blockquote><p><span>“Most manufacturers are ramping up their development in areas such as electric vehicles and driverless cars but it will ultimately be the consumer that will determine who the winners are.”</span></p>\n<p><span>“We have already seen some early signs of changes in this industry, particularly in the very rapid changes in fuel preferences, the move aware from cars to SUVs and the speed and range of new models entering the market.”</span></p>\n</blockquote>","category":["car loans","Roy Morgan"],"coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/e836e1529b0c8683706ac90e06831a2a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Mark Bristow","compliedAuthor":"55","content:encoded":"<p><span></span><span>More Australians have made plans to buy a new car this year, according to Roy Morgan. But as well as considering the costs of car loans and financing for their new vehicles a growing number of Aussies are also considering vehicles with alternative fuel supplies.</span><span> </span></p>\n<h3>More new car purchases forecast for 2018</h3>\n<p><span>The results of the Roy Morgan Single Source Survey show that as of December 2017, the number of Australians intending to buy a new vehicle in the next 12 months grew by 44,000 to 614,000 – a 7.7% increase on the results from the same time last year. </span></p>\n<p><span>Looking at the longer term, Australian car buying intentions over the next four years were found to have dropped by 2.29% to 2.26 million from the same time last year. However, with the industry experiencing record sales in 2017 (according to Roy Morgan), this could indicate a positive 2018 outlook for the industry.</span></p>\n<h3>New cars with new fuels</h3>\n<p><span>According to VFACTS data, 75.3% of new vehicles sold in Australia last year had petrol engines. According to Roy Morgan, of the 2.26 million Aussies looking to buy over the next four years, only 61.9% thought that their next vehicle will most likely have a petrol engine.</span></p>\n<div class=\"table-responsive\">\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered table-condensed table-hover\">\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th>Fuel type</th>\n<th>Sales share in 2017 (VFACTS)</th>\n<th>New car intenders over next 4 years (Roy Morgan)</th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>Petrol</td>\n<td>75.3%</td>\n<td>61.9%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Diesel</td>\n<td>24.1%</td>\n<td>29.2%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>LPG</td>\n<td>0.0%</td>\n<td>0.6%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Hybrid</td>\n<td>0.5%</td>\n<td>5.2%</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Electric</td>\n<td>0.1%</td>\n<td>3.1%</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<p><small><em>Source: <a href=\"http://www.roymorgan.com/findings/7532-more-than-2-million-intend-to-purchase-a-new-vehicle-but-what-fuel-201803150007\">Roy Morgan</a></em></small></p>\n</div>\n<p><span>The primary alternative to standard petrol was diesel, with its preference level for new purchases over the next 4 years up 5.3% points to 29.2%, compared to the 2017 VFACTS sales data. Preference levels for hybrid (petrol and electric) cars was up by 4.7% points to 5.2%; fully electric cars by 3.0% points to 3.1%; and LPG-fuelled cars from 0% to 0.6%.</span></p>\n<h3>The challenge ahead</h3>\n<p><span>Roy Morgan industry communications director, Norman Morris, said that while the new vehicle market has experienced growth over the past decade, it is now facing the challenge of rapidly changing technologies and fuel preferences:</span></p>\n<blockquote><p><span>“Most manufacturers are ramping up their development in areas such as electric vehicles and driverless cars but it will ultimately be the consumer that will determine who the winners are.”</span></p>\n<p><span>“We have already seen some early signs of changes in this industry, particularly in the very rapid changes in fuel preferences, the move aware from cars to SUVs and the speed and range of new models entering the market.”</span></p>\n</blockquote>","created_at":"1521454732","dc:creator":"Mark Bristow","description":"More Australians have made plans to buy a new car this year, according to Roy Morgan. 2017.","slider_data":[],"slug":"lexus-voted-best-for-customer-satisfaction","status":"publish","supplierReference":null,"supplier_reference":null,"thumbnail_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180226112436/iStock-4585799651-350x500.jpg","title":"Lexus Bristow","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span></span><span>Australia’s transport costs were up over the 2017 December quarter, with rises to the cost of fuel, tolls and insurance outpacing falls in the cost of car loans, servicing and registration, according to the Australian Automobile Association (AAA).</span></p>\n<p><span>According to the AAA December 2017 Transport Affordability Index, the average Australian metropolitan household&#8217;s transport spending over the quarter rose by $121 to $17,606, accounting for 14.2% of household income. Regional households were found to have seen their transport costs rise by $125 to $14,008, accounting for 12.3% of household income.</span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>Overall, the transport costs that increased over the quarter included:</span><span> </span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><span>Fuel prices</span></li>\n<li><span>Comprehensive insurance</span></li>\n<li><span>Toll costs</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span>Costs that decreased over the quarter included:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><span>Car loan payments</span></li>\n<li><span>Registration, CTP and licensing fees</span></li>\n<li><span>Servicing of the old vehicle and tyres for both vehicles</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span>While car loan payments across Australia dropped slightly over the December 2017 quarter, they still remained the number one highest-priced transport expense for both metro and regional households. Melbourne and Geelong were found to be the most expensive metro and regional centres in terms of car loan costs (despite a large decrease in Melbourne), while the cheapest car loan payments were found in Hobart and Launceston.</span></p>\n<p><span>Only Sydney, Wagga Wagga and Hobart recorded decreases in overall transport costs for the December 2017 quarter, by $58, $80 and $24 respectively. Despite this decrease, Sydney remained the most expensive capital city in Australia in terms of total dollars at $22,291 per year.</span></p>\n<p><span>AAA chief executive, Michael Bradley, described the impact of transport on the cost of living as being “frequently overlooked” compared to utilities such as electricity: </span></p>\n<blockquote><p><span>“Unlike utility bills, Australian families do not receive all-encompassing transport bills every three months. The index highlights subtle movements in transport costs, which are otherwise easy to overlook.”</span></p>\n</blockquote>\n<h3>Total annual household transport costs</h3>\n<div class=\"table-responsive\">\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered table-condensed table-hover\">\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th>City</th>\n<th>Q3</th>\n<th>Q4</th>\n<th>Change</th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>Sydney</td>\n<td>$22,349.84</td>\n<td>$22,291.81</td>\n<td>-$58.03</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Melbourne</td>\n<td>$19,306.85</td>\n<td>$19,461.26</td>\n<td>$154.41</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Brisbane</td>\n<td>$19,066.86</td>\n<td>$19,312.22</td>\n<td>$245.36</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Perth</td>\n<td>$17,022.71</td>\n<td>$17,218.64</td>\n<td>$195.93</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Adelaide</td>\n<td>$15,404.80</td>\n<td>$15,624.97</td>\n<td>$220.17</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Hobart</td>\n<td>$15,001.63</td>\n<td>$14,977.64</td>\n<td>-$23.98</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Darwin</td>\n<td>$15,288.65</td>\n<td>$15,372.69</td>\n<td>$84.04</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Canberra</td>\n<td>$16,439.78</td>\n<td>$16,589.75</td>\n<td>$149.97</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><strong>Capital cost"],"coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/e836e1529b0c8683706ac90e06831a2a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Mark Bristow","compliedAuthor":"55","content:encoded":"<p><span></span><span>Australia’s transport costs were up over the 2017 December quarter, with rises to the cost of fuel, tolls and insurance outpacing falls in the cost of car loans, servicing and registration, according to the Australian Automobile Association (AAA).</span></p>\n<p><span>According to the AAA December 2017 Transport Affordability Index, the average Australian metropolitan household&#8217;s transport spending over the quarter rose by $121 to $17,606, accounting for 14.2% of household income. Regional households were found to have seen their transport costs rise by $125 to $14,008, accounting for 12.3% of household income.</span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>Overall, the transport costs that increased over the quarter included:</span><span> </span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><span>Fuel prices</span></li>\n<li><span>Comprehensive insurance</span></li>\n<li><span>Toll costs</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span>Costs that decreased over the quarter included:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><span>Car loan payments</span></li>\n<li><span>Registration, CTP and licensing fees</span></li>\n<li><span>Servicing of the old vehicle and tyres for both vehicles</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span>While car loan payments across Australia dropped slightly over the December 2017 quarter, they still remained the number one highest-priced transport expense for both metro and regional households. Melbourne and Geelong were found to be the most expensive metro and regional centres in terms of car loan costs (despite a large decrease in Melbourne), while the cheapest car loan payments were found in Hobart and Launceston.</span></p>\n<p><span>Only Sydney, Wagga Wagga and Hobart recorded decreases in overall transport costs for the December 2017 quarter, by $58, $80 and $24 respectively. Despite this decrease, Sydney remained the most expensive capital city in Australia in terms of total dollars at $22,291 per year.</span></p>\n<p><span>AAA chief executive, Michael Bradley, described the impact of transport on the cost of living as being “frequently overlooked” compared to utilities such as electricity: </span></p>\n<blockquote><p><span>“Unlike utility bills, Australian families do not receive all-encompassing transport bills every three months. The index highlights subtle movements in transport costs, which are otherwise easy to overlook.”</span></p>\n</blockquote>\n<h3>Total annual household transport costs</h3>\n<div quarter, with rises to the cost of fuel, tolls and insurance outpacing falls in the cost of car loans, servicing and registration, according to the Australian Automobile Association (AAA).","slider_data":[],"slug":"cheaper-car-loans-fail-offset-rising-transport-costs","status":"publish","supplierReference":null,"supplier_reference":null,"thumbnail_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180219102044/car-costs-350x500.jpg","title":"Cheaper car loans fail to offset rising transport costs","type":"article","updated_at":"1519035983","url":"/car-loans/news/cheaper-car-loans-fail-offset-rising-transport-costs","uses_markdown":"false"},{"SEO_Smart_Links":"[null,null,\"\",\"\",null]","_edit_last":"44","_edit_lock":"1518131087:59","_yoast_wpseo_metadesc":"There’s been an increase in the number of Australians who intend to buy a vehicle in the next four years, with the number rising to 2.38 million.","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"car-loans","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Alex Ritchie","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>There’s been an increase in the number of Australians who intend to buy a vehicle in the next four years, with the number rising to 2.38 million.</p>\n<p>The latest Roy Morgan Single survey of over 50,000 consumers found that in the three months leading to November 2017, the number rose by 142,000 people looking to buy a new vehicle.</p>\n<p>The survey also found that those looking to buy a new car are more confident than the population average. “Over the November quarter, the consumer confidence for all Australians was 114.1, whereas those intending to purchase a new vehicle in the next four years had a much higher level with 122.8.”</p>\n<h4><strong>New vehicle purchase intention: November 2017</strong></h4>\n<p><img style=\"width: 70%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180205143654/7475-c1.png\" /></p>\n<p>Source: <a href=\"http://www.roymorgan.com/findings/7475-new-vehicle-buying-intentions-up-142000-201802020506\">Roy Morgan Single Source</a></p>\n<p>Intentions to buy a vehicle in the next 12 months have also risen by 13,000 (2.2 per cent) over the same period last year, to 615,000. This segment also had higher than average consumer confidence than the general population.<strong> </strong></p>\n<h3><strong>Over 50s are most interested in buying new vehicles</strong></h3>\n<p>Roy Morgan also found that those 50 and over had the strongest growth with new vehicle purchase intent in the next four years. Those aged 65 or over had the highest growth rate, increasing by almost 250 per cent to 420,000. This was followed by the 50-64 age group, who saw intent rise 36 per cent.</p>\n<p>Those under 35 all saw a decrease in new vehicle purchase intent in the next four years, with the strongest decrease coming from those aged 14-24 (falling 29 per cent).</p>\n<p>According to Roy Morgan, these age groups are “demonstrating less interest in purchasing new motor vehicles but they remain the highest intenders for used vehicles.”</p>\n<h4><strong>New vehicle purchase intenders in next 4 years by age</strong></h4>\n<p><img style=\"width: 70%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180205143655/7475-c2.png\" /></p>\n<p><em>Source: <a href=\"http://www.roymorgan.com/findings/7475-new-vehicle-buying-intentions-up-142000-201802020506\">Roy Morgan Single Source</a></em></p>\n<p>Norman Morris, Industry Communications Director, Roy Morgan said that over the last decade or more, there has been “considerable growth in the new vehicle market generated in part by higher confidence among buyers and reflected in recent record sales and buying intentions.”</p>\n<blockquote><p>“The increase in the trend for new vehicle purchasing intentions that we have seen over the last 15 years has come mainly from the over 50s age group and in particular those over 65.</p>\n<p>“The under 35 age groups on the other hand have shown a long term decline in new vehicle buying intention levels. This is likely due to a number of factors including competing priorities in areas such as travel, dining out, housing costs etc. and income related factors caused by unemployment and longer time spent in higher education. This group has not lost interest in motor vehicles as shown by their very high intention levels to purchase a used vehicle.</p>\n<p>“With the speed of change taking place in this industry currently, particularly in areas such as electric cars, it is important to track consumers’ likely interest in these potential fuel changes.</p>\n<p>Currently, 37% of the population say that they would seriously consider purchasing an electric vehicle, up from 29% just one year ago. This is now not far below the level of interest in diesel with 45% and well ahead of LPG on 21%, both of which are showing downward trends.</p>\n<p>“The changes in technology such as driverless cars and fuel preferences have the potential to impact rapidly on vehicle purchasing intentions as they can be regarded as major disrupters,” said Mr Morris.</p>\n</blockquote>","category":["car industry","new cars","Roy Morgan"],"coauthor_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Alex Ritchie","compliedAuthor":"55","content:encoded":"<p>There’s been an increase in the number of Australians who intend to buy a vehicle in the next four years, with the number rising to 2.38 million.</p>\n<p>The latest Roy Morgan Single survey of over 50,000 consumers found that in the three months leading to November 2017, the number rose by 142,000 people looking to buy a new vehicle.</p>\n<p>The survey also found that those looking to buy a new car are more confident than the population average. “Over the November quarter, the consumer confidence for all Australians was 114.1, whereas those intending to purchase a new vehicle in the next four years had a much higher level with 122.8.”</p>\n<h4><strong>New vehicle purchase intention: November 2017</strong></h4>\n<p><img style=\"width: 70%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180205143654/7475-c1.png\" /></p>\n<p>Source: <a href=\"http://www.roymorgan.com/findings/7475-new-vehicle-buying-intentions-up-142000-201802020506\">Roy Morgan Single Source</a></p>\n<p>Intentions to buy a vehicle in the next 12 months have also risen by 13,000 (2.2 per cent) over the same period last year, to 615,000. This segment also had higher than average consumer confidence than the general population.<strong> </strong></p>\n<h3><strong>Over 50s are most interested in buying new vehicles</strong></h3>\n<p>Roy Morgan also found that those 50 and over had the strongest growth with new vehicle purchase intent in the next four years. Those aged 65 or over had the highest growth rate, increasing by almost 250 per cent to 420,000. This was followed by the 50-64 age group, who saw intent rise 36 per cent.</p>\n<p>Those under 35 all saw a decrease in new vehicle purchase intent in the next four years, with the strongest decrease coming from those aged 14-24 (falling 29 per cent).</p>\n<p>According to Roy Morgan, these age groups are “demonstrating less interest in purchasing new motor vehicles but they remain the highest intenders for used vehicles.”</p>\n<h4><strong>New vehicle purchase intenders in next 4 years by age</strong></h4>\n<p><img style=\"width: 70%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180205143655/7475-c2.png\" /></p>\n<p><em>Source: <a href=\"http://www.roymorgan.com/findings/7475-new-vehicle-buying-intentions-up-142000-201802020506\">Roy Morgan Single Source</a></em></p>\n<p>Norman Morris, Industry Communications Director, Roy Morgan said that over the last decade or more, there has been “considerable growth in the new vehicle market generated in part by higher confidence among buyers and reflected in recent record sales and buying intentions.”</p>\n<blockquote><p>“The increase in the trend for new vehicle purchasing intentions that we have seen over the last 15 years has come mainly from the over 50s age group and in particular those over 65.</p>\n<p>“The under 35 age groups on the other hand have shown a long term decline in new vehicle buying intention levels. This is likely due to a number of factors including competing priorities in areas such as travel, dining out, housing costs etc. and income related factors caused by unemployment and longer time spent in higher education. This group has not lost interest in motor vehicles as shown by their very high intention levels to purchase a used vehicle.</p>\n<p>“With the speed of change taking place in this industry currently, particularly in areas such as electric cars, it is important to track consumers’ likely interest in these potential fuel changes.</p>\n<p>Currently, 37% of the population say that they would seriously consider purchasing an electric vehicle, up from 29% just one year ago. This is now not far below the level of interest in diesel with 45% and well ahead of LPG on 21%, both of which are showing downward trends.</p>\n<p>“The changes in technology such as driverless cars and fuel preferences have the potential to impact rapidly on vehicle purchasing intentions as they can be regarded as major disrupters,” said Mr Morris.</p>\n</blockquote>","created_at":"1517841536","dc:creator":"Alex Ritchie","description":"There’s been an increase in the number of Australians who intend to buy a vehicle in the next four years, with the number rising to 2.38 million. More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h3>Insurance can be added onto loan</h3>\n<p>Consumers who are unsure what car they want can get a loan pre-approved before the search for a vehicle begins.</p>\n<p>When the loan is being finalised, consumers can sign up for Allianz Value Protect Insurance, which combines gap cover and purchase price insurance.</p>\n<p>This insurance cover can then be added to the loan, so it is gradually paid off over the course of the loan.</p>\n<p>Consumers can borrow between $10,000 and $250,000 over one to seven years, and repay the loan in fortnightly or monthly instalments.</p>\n<p>The loan includes a $505 establishment fee and $8.10 monthly service fee.</p>","category":["ing","ing You simply tell them what you&#8217;re looking for,” <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/ing-direct\">ING Direct</a> said.</p>\n<p>“They&#8217;ll then find your new car, do all the negotiating with a network of over 500 dealerships and help you apply for an <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/ing-direct\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">ING Direct</a> car loan too.”</p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Regulator takes action</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Car customers get $72.7m of refunds</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/car-loans/news/car-customers-get-72-7m-refunds\">Read More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h3>Insurance can be added onto loan</h3>\n<p>Consumers who are unsure what car they want can get a loan pre-approved before the search for a vehicle begins.</p>\n<p>When the loan is being finalised, consumers can sign up for Allianz Value Protect Insurance, which combines gap cover and purchase price insurance.</p>\n<p>This insurance cover can then be added to the loan, so it is gradually paid off over the course of the loan.</p>\n<p>Consumers can borrow between $10,000 and $250,000 over one to seven years, and repay the loan in fortnightly or monthly instalments.</p>\n<p>The loan includes a $505 establishment fee and $8.10 monthly service fee.</p>","created_at":"1516800424","dc:creator":"Nick Bendel","description":"ING Direct has launched a car product that combines finance with a vehicle-buying service. The new product is a partnership between ING and Macquarie Leasing – it will carry the ING brand, but the finance and buying service will be provided by Macquarie. ING Direct said the two-in-one product would make life simpler for consumers. &#8230; <a href=\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/new-car-loan-includes-car-buying-service/\" class=\"more-link\">Continue reading<span class=\"screen-reader-text\"> \"New car loan includes car-buying service\"</span></a>","exclusive_to_partner":"false","faq_description":null,"guid":{"$t":"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=73320","isPermaLink":"false"},"has_video":"false","header_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170222130150/iStock-501619772-724x420.jpg","id":73320,"link":"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/new-car-loan-includes-car-buying-service/","media_release":null,"overallRating":null,"page_header":null,"page_subheader":null,"partner_name":null,"post_id":"73320","pubDate":"Wed, 24 Jan 2018 03:27:04 +0000","publish_until":null,"question":null,"quote":null,"readingTime":2,"result_name":null,"short_description":"ING Direct has launched a car product that combines finance with a vehicle-buying service.","slider_data":[],"slug":"new-car-loan-includes-car-buying-service","status":"publish","supplierReference":null,"supplier_reference":null,"thumbnail_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20170222130150/iStock-501619772-350x483.jpg","title":"New car loan includes car-buying service","type":"article","updated_at":"1516800424","url":"/car-loans/news/new-car-loan-includes-car-buying-service","uses_markdown":"false"}],"creditCards":[{"SEO_Smart_Links":"[null,null,\"\",\"\",null]","_edit_last":"44","_edit_lock":"1527816669:44","_yoast_wpseo_metadesc":"Planning a big one this weekend? You might want to triple check your credit card is still in your wallet, as 8am Monday morning is the most common time for Aussies to report their card as lost or stolen.","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"credit-cards","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Alex Ritchie","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>Planning a big one this weekend? You might want to triple check your credit card is still in your wallet, as 8am Monday morning is the most common time for Aussies to report their card as lost or stolen.</p>\n<p>Research from industry super fund-owned bank, ME, has found that in the past 12 months around 12,000 ME customers reported their credit or debit card as either lost or stolen, and 8am Monday is around when they realise.</p>\n<p>Gen X-ers were also reported as the worst offenders, with more than a third of missing card reports coming from these customers.</p>\n<p>ME Money Expert, Matthew Read, put the blame on “big weekends” for the spike in Monday morning reports.</p>\n<p>“That there’s a surge in the number of people reporting lost or stolen cards at 8am Monday suggests something went awry on the weekend, with many only realising their loss trying to buy their first coffee of the week,” said Mr Read.</p>\n<p>“Reporting a lost or stolen card quickly lets your bank put a stop on your card so that no one else can access your money.</p>\n<p>“Most banks have a 24-hour telephone number for reporting lost or stolen cards.</p>\n<p>“These days most banks, including ME, allow customers to block and unblock lost cards via a banking app on their phone,” said Mr Read.</p>\n<p>If you’re planning on having a ‘big weekend’, ensure you’re with a card provider who prioritises customers with lost or stolen cards.</p>","category":["credit cards","security","stolen card"],"coauthor_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Alex Ritchie","compliedAuthor":"55","content:encoded":"<p>Planning a big one this weekend? Ritchie","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>Treating yourself while on holiday may be one of life’s small joys, but breaking the holiday budget is costing Aussies a collective $4.6 billion a year.</p>\n<p>New research from <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\">Commonwealth Bank</a> into <span><a href=\"https://www.commbank.com.au/guidance/newsroom/winging-the-holiday-budget-201805.html\">holiday spending</a></span> has found that:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>More than one in two (58 per cent) of travellers will return home with an unwanted financial souvenir;</li>\n<li>Aussies on average overspend their holiday budgets by more than $1,554 per person &#8211; $4.6 billion in total;</li>\n<li>A quarter (26 per cent) of Aussies don’t save any spending money before travelling;</li>\n<li>One in five (21 per cent) travel without a holiday budget;</li>\n<li>Only one in three (36 per cent) of travellers check their spending each day while on vacation; and</li>\n<li>Over a quarter (28 per cent) report having to make ‘sacrifices’ when they returned home (including choosing to stay in on weekends and eat cheaply).</li>\n</ul>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Time for sandy beaches and palm trees</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">What are the best travel cards?</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/bank-accounts/articles/best-travel-cards-take-overseas\">Find out now</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Michael Baumann, General Manager Everyday Banking and Payments, <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/commonwealth-bank\">Commonwealth Bank</a>, said “it might sound obvious but a little research goes a long way with 38 per cent saying the advice they received was very accurate and gave them a good idea of how much money was needed”.</p>\n<blockquote><p><em>“Despite advice from family and friends and budgeting tips and tricks for travellers online, over half (55 per cent) said they made an educated guess when working out their holiday spending money.</em></p>\n<p><em>“Even more concerning was that a third (33 per cent) aren’t putting aside extra spending money for unexpected expenses or overspend.</em></p>\n<p><em>“It’s always advisable to set aside emergency savings that can easily be accessed or transferred from your mobile banking app to your Travel Money Card when unexpected situations arise.</em></p>\n<p><em>“It’s also important that travellers are realistic about what they can afford while travelling and keep track of their spending to ensure they are sticking to their holiday budget,” said Mr Baumann.</em></p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>&nbsp;</p>\n<h3>Credit cards for overseas
