Holiday overspending costing Aussies $4.6 billion\"</span></a>","exclusive_to_partner":"false","faq_description":null,"guid":{"$t":"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=76399","isPermaLink":"false"},"has_video":"false","header_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180529113444/iStock-873385094-1024x768.jpg","id":76399,"link":"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/budget-holiday-overspending-costing-aussies-4-6-billion/","media_release":null,"overallRating":null,"page_header":null,"page_subheader":null,"partner_name":null,"post_id":"76399","pubDate":"Tue, 29 May 2018 01:35:21 +0000","publish_until":null,"question":null,"quote":null,"readingTime":2,"result_name":null,"short_description":"Treating yourself while on holiday may be one of life’s small joys, but breaking the holiday budget is costing Aussies a collective $4.6 billion a year.","slider_data":[],"slug":"budget-holiday-overspending-costing-aussies-4-6-billion","status":"publish","supplierReference":null,"supplier_reference":null,"thumbnail_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20180529113457/iStock-8733850941-350x500.jpg","title":"What budget? Holiday overspending costing Aussies $4.6 billion","type":"article","updated_at":"1527593853","url":"/credit-cards/news/budget-holiday-overspending-costing-aussies-4-6-billion","uses_markdown":"false"},{"SEO_Smart_Links":"[null,null,\"\",\"\",null]","_edit_last":"44","_edit_lock":"1526962611:44","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"credit-cards","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Alex Ritchie","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>New research from RateCity shows banks are ramping up credit card repayment plans following the lightening success of Afterpay, with Australia’s biggest bank, Commonwealth also due to launch a repayment offering in coming weeks.</p>\n<p>Credit card repayment plans have become a popular option over the last year, with prominent credit card providers such as AMEX, <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Bankwest</a>, <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/citibank\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Citibank</a>, <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/ing-direct\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">ING Direct</a> and <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/virgin-money\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Virgin Money</a> all choosing to offer a repayment feature.</p>\n<p>Repayment plans allow the cardholder to take a large purchase, a bundle of purchases, or even cash, and repay it in fixed amounts over an agreed period at a reduced interest rate of as little as 0 per cent.</p>\n<h3>But are they a good idea?</h3>\n<p>RateCity’s spokesperson, Sally Tindall, said these plans can get people out of a tight financial spot, but needed to be used with extreme caution.</p>\n<p>“Credit card repayment plans can help if you need to buy an essential item and don’t have the cash to cover it, but only if you’re diligent about paying back the debt,” she said.</p>\n<p>“But credit card repayment plans are riddled with hidden traps, that can trip up even the most discerning user.</p>\n<p>“The main problem is when you start skipping repayments. No-one comes after you with a big stick. Instead what they’ll typically do is start applying the standard interest rate on what’s likely to be a significant credit card debt.</p>\n<p>“The card provided will also go back to asking for just the minimum repayments, which could see your debt spiral out of control.</p>\n<p>“One alternative for big ticket items is to take out a low rate <a href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/best?pl_showAll=true&ab_test_id=0\">personal loan</a>. They force people to make regular repayments to pay off the debt in full, without the temptation to rack up more debt.</p>\n<p>“Buy now, pay later services, such as Afterpay, are another option. With no interest and no upfront fees, it’s a cheap way to secure credit – provided you don’t miss any repayments.</p>\n<p>“The problem with Afterpay is that the service is predominantly used for non-essential items. It’s one thing to borrow money to replace a broken fridge or to pay the gas bill, but when it comes to luxury items, we’d recommend people finance it the old fashion way – save up for it,” she said.</p>\n<h4>Credit card repayment plans &#8211; potential traps</h4>\n<ol>\n<li>Not meeting a repayment, and getting charged the standard purchase rate.</li>\n<li>Failing to clear the debt within the repayment period.</li>\n<li>Losing your interest free days on purchases you put on a repayment plan.</li>\n<li>Paying fees to use the service.</li>\n</ol>\n<p><em>Note: the terms and conditions are different for each card. Not every trap is applicable to each card.</em></p>\n<h3><strong>Credit card repayment plans</strong></h3>\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered table-hover table-condensed\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Bank</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Reduced rate</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Loan term</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Instalment fees</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Interest free days?</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Fine print</strong></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p><a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">American Express</a></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>0%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>3, 6 or 12 months</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Set-up fee of 2-4%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Yes but not on instalments.</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Once you set up a plan, every purchase over the nominated amount will go on to a payment plan and incur a fee. Does not allow extra repayments.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>Bankwest</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>0.00% &#8211; 3.99%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>3 mths –</p>\n<p>6 mths</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>No</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Yes but not on instalments.</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>No penalty for missing a repayment but any balance owing at the end of the fixed term will be charged at the purchase rate after one month.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>Citi</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>7.90% p.a. to 12.99%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>1 &#8211; 5 years</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>No</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Yes but not on instalments.</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>If you miss a repayment the purchase rate will apply. You can make additional repayments but the money will go towards your standard credit card bill first.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>ING</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>9.99%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>3 mths –</p>\n<p>7 yrs</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>No</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Yes &#8211; both instalment and normal purchases</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>No penalty for missing a repayment but any balance owing at the end of the fixed term will be charged at the purchase rate.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>Latitude Financial Go Mastercard</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>0%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>From 3 mths</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>$25 setup fee and a $4.95 mthly fee</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Yes but not on instalments.</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Only for purchases at affiliated stores. If the contract is terminated or comes to an end with an outstanding balance it will attract a rate of 29.49%.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<p><em>Note: selected fine print only. Always read the full terms and conditions before taking out a credit card.</em></p>","category":["credit cards","repayments"],"coauthor_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Alex Ritchie","compliedAuthor":"18","content:encoded":"<p>New research from RateCity shows banks are ramping up credit card repayment plans following the lightening success of Afterpay, with Australia’s biggest bank, Commonwealth also due to launch a repayment offering in coming weeks.</p>\n<p>Credit card repayment plans have become a popular option over the last year, with prominent credit card providers such as AMEX, <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/bankwest\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Bankwest</a>, <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/citibank\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Citibank</a>, <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/ing-direct\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">ING Direct</a> and <a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/virgin-money\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">Virgin Money</a> all choosing to offer a repayment feature.</p>\n<p>Repayment plans allow the cardholder to take a large purchase, a bundle of purchases, or even cash, and repay it in fixed amounts over an agreed period at a reduced interest rate of as little as 0 per cent.</p>\n<h3>But are they a good idea?</h3>\n<p>RateCity’s spokesperson, Sally Tindall, said these plans can get people out of a tight financial spot, but needed to be used with extreme caution.</p>\n<p>“Credit card repayment plans can help if you need to buy an essential item and don’t have the cash to cover it, but only if you’re diligent about paying back the debt,” she said.</p>\n<p>“But credit card repayment plans are riddled with hidden traps, that can trip up even the most discerning user.</p>\n<p>“The main problem is when you start skipping repayments. No-one comes after you with a big stick. Instead what they’ll typically do is start applying the standard interest rate on what’s likely to be a significant credit card debt.</p>\n<p>“The card provided will also go back to asking for just the minimum repayments, which could see your debt spiral out of control.</p>\n<p>“One alternative for big ticket items is to take out a low rate <a href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/personal-loans/best?pl_showAll=true&ab_test_id=0\">personal loan</a>. They force people to make regular repayments to pay off the debt in full, without the temptation to rack up more debt.</p>\n<p>“Buy now, pay later services, such as Afterpay, are another option. With no interest and no upfront fees, it’s a cheap way to secure credit – provided you don’t miss any repayments.</p>\n<p>“The problem with Afterpay is that the service is predominantly used for non-essential items. It’s one thing to borrow money to replace a broken fridge or to pay the gas bill, but when it comes to luxury items, we’d recommend people finance it the old fashion way – save up for it,” she said.</p>\n<h4>Credit card repayment plans &#8211; potential traps</h4>\n<ol>\n<li>Not meeting a repayment, and getting charged the standard purchase rate.</li>\n<li>Failing to clear the debt within the repayment period.</li>\n<li>Losing your interest free days on purchases you put on a repayment plan.</li>\n<li>Paying fees to use the service.</li>\n</ol>\n<p><em>Note: the terms and conditions are different for each card. Not every trap is applicable to each card.</em></p>\n<h3><strong>Credit card repayment plans</strong></h3>\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered table-hover table-condensed\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Bank</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Reduced rate</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Loan term</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Instalment fees</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Interest free days?</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Fine print</strong></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p><a href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"rc-keyword\">American Express</a></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>0%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>3, 6 or 12 months</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Set-up fee of 2-4%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Yes but not on instalments.</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Once you set up a plan, every purchase over the nominated amount will go on to a payment plan and incur a fee. Does not allow extra repayments.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>Bankwest</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>0.00% &#8211; 3.99%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>3 mths –</p>\n<p>6 mths</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>No</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Yes but not on instalments.</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>No penalty for missing a repayment but any balance owing at the end of the fixed term will be charged at the purchase rate after one month.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>Citi</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>7.90% p.a. to 12.99%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>1 &#8211; 5 years</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>No</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Yes but not on instalments.</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>If you miss a repayment the purchase rate will apply. You can make additional repayments but the money will go towards your standard credit card bill first.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>ING</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>9.99%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>3 mths –</p>\n<p>7 yrs</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>No</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Yes &#8211; both instalment and normal purchases</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>No penalty for missing a repayment but any balance owing at the end of the fixed term will be charged at the purchase rate.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>Latitude Financial Go Mastercard</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>0%</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>From 3 mths</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>$25 setup fee and a $4.95 mthly fee</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Yes but not on instalments.</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>Only for purchases at affiliated stores. If the contract is terminated or comes to an end with an outstanding balance it will attract a rate of 29.49%.</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<p><em>Note: selected fine print only. Always read the full terms and conditions before taking out a credit card.</em></p>","created_at":"1526998609","dc:creator":"Alex Ritchie","description":"New research from RateCity shows banks are ramping up credit card repayment plans following the lightening success of Afterpay, with Australia’s biggest bank, Commonwealth also due to launch a repayment offering in coming weeks. end of April 2018, down from 16.89% at the end of March 2018.</span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>The April average rate is the lowest recorded over the past year, which topped out at 17.05% in July 2017, and has been falling since January 2018.</span></p>\n<p><span></span><span>These falling average credit card interest rates are representative of a trend recently observed in the credit card Bristow","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span></span><span>The latest change to credit card interest rates from <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\">American Express</a> could see Australians clear their card debts a year and a quarter sooner, saving hundreds of dollars in interest payments, according to RateCity calculations. </span><span> </span></p>\n<p><span>The <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\">American Express</a> Low Rate Credit Card saw its interest rate fall from 11.99% to 8.99% on 9 April 2018 for existing customers, and from 11 April 2018 for new customers. While this relatively simple card lacks access to the Amex reward programs, it does allow cardholders to enjoy Amex Offers, and no annual fee.</span></p>\n<p><span>RateCity has calculated that with this interest rate reduction, if an Australian with an average credit card debt of $4198 chose to only make the minimum required repayments, they would clear their debt one year and three months sooner, saving $802 in interest charges.</span></p>\n<div class=\"table-responsive\">\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered table-hover table-condensed\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<th>Interest charged on 11.99%, min repay of 2.5% or $30</th>\n<td>$6501</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Interest charged on 8.99%, min repay of 2.5% or $30</th>\n<td>$5699</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Money saved</th>\n<td>$802</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th>Time saved</th>\n<td>1 year, 3 months</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n</div>\n<p>The<span> rate change from <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\">American Express</a> is the latest example of a trend sweeping through </span><span> Australia’s credit card marketplace, though over the past 14 months, while several lenders have introduced new low rate credit cards, relatively few have cut rates on their existing cards:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li><span>CBA introduced a new &#8220;essentials&#8221; credit card early in 2018 with a rate of 9.90% (equal 6th lowest on RateCity)</span></li>\n<li><span><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\">Westpac</a> introduced a new &#8220;lite&#8221; credit card in mid 2017 with a rate of 9.90% (equal 6th lowest on RateCity)</span></li>\n<li><span>ING introduced a credit card to existing customers with a rate of 11.99% and no annual fee in May 2017</span></li>\n<li><span><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/hsbc\">HSBC</a> introduced a new low rate credit card in February 2017 with a rate of 13.25%</span></li>\n<li><span><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/anz\">ANZ</a> cut the rates on their low rate platinum card from 13.49% to 11.49% and their low rate classic card from 13.49% to 12.49%</span></li>\n</ul>\n<div class=\"table-responsive\">\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered table-condensed table-hover\">\n<thead>\n<tr>\n<th>Company</th>\n<th>Card</th>\n<th>Rate</th>\n<th>Annual fee</th>\n<th>Interest free days (up to)</th>\n<th>Perks</th>\n<th>Cons</th>\n</tr>\n</thead>\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\">American Express</a></td>\n<td>Low Rate</td>\n<td>8.99%</td>\n<td>$0</td>\n<td>55</td>\n<td>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">0% p.a. on BTs for the first 12 months, purchase protection and refund protection</span></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">Late payment fee of $30. Amex not accepted everywhere</span></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\"><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/community-first-cu\">Community First Credit Union</a></span></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p class=\"p1\"><span class=\"s1\">Low Rate Visa / McGrath Pink Visa</span></p>\n</td>\n<td>8.99%</td>\n<td>$40</td>\n<td>55</td>\n<td>Low rate, low annual fee</td>\n<td>Late payment fee of $25</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>Easy Street Credit Union</td>\n<td>Easy Low href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/american-express\">American Express</a> as great news for people looking for a low rate credit card, adding that the market is slowly shifting, and that more lenders are expected to follow suit in the next 12 months. </span></p>\n<blockquote><p><em>“Customers should never accept rates as high as 24.99 per cent just for the privilege of using their plastic.”</em></p>\n<p><em>“If you’re using a high rate card, it’s time to start looking for a new deal.  There are plenty of offers on the market with low rates and low annual fees, some even offer rewards.”</em></p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>It&#8217;s important to remember that the credit cards with the lowest interest rates may not always be the best options for every borrower. Bendel","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">There are several dozen credit cards in Australia that currently offer 0 per cent balance transfers for at least one year.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Consumers who want to consolidate their credit card debt can, for example, transfer their balance to the <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/hsbc\">HSBC</a> Platinum Credit Card and pay 0 per cent interest on that debt for 22 months (see table below).</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">At the end of that 22-month balance transfer period, <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/hsbc\">HSBC</a> will charge an ongoing purchase rate of 21.99 per cent.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/hsbc\">HSBC</a> allows consumers to transfer debt equivalent to 100 per cent of their credit limit &#8211; so if the limit on their new credit card is $5,000, they can transfer a maximum balance of $5,000.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">However, they have to pay a balance transfer fee of 2 per cent, which would be $100 on a $5,000 balance transfer.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">As a general rule, while balance transfer credit cards might offer interest-free periods on old credit card debt, they will charge interest on any new credit card debt racked up on the new card.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">It’s also important to note that a credit card with the longest balance transfer period might not be as suitable to some consumers as credit cards with a shorter balance transfer period.</span></p>\n<h3>Some of the best balance transfer offers</h3>\n<div class=\"table-responsive\">\n<table class=\"table Bristow","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span></span><span><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\">Westpac</a> has confirmed it plans to offer least-cost routing for contactless debit card payments, which could allow retailers to lower operating costs and pass the savings on to Australian shoppers. </span></p>\n<p><span>Last year, the Reserve Bank of Australia&#8217;s (RBA) Payment Systems Board recommended that regulations be put in place to ensure banks give merchants the ability to send tap-and-go payments from dual-network debit cards through the channel of their choice, if the banks had not already facilitated this recommendation by 1 April 2018.</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">RBA payments policy:</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">RBA looks at more affordable electronic payments</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/news/rba-looks-affordable-electronic-payments\">Read More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><span>Westpac is currently in discussion with the RBA regarding its plans, which are due to be put into action in 2019.</span></p>\n<div class=\"breakout breakout-tip\">\n<div class=\"breakout-heading\">\n<p class=\"breakout-title\">What is least-cost routing?</p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"breakout-body\">\n<p>Many payment systems currently used in shops around Australia automatically rout contactless card payments through payment networks owned by the likes of Visa and Mastercard.</p>\n<p>This means that even if a shopper pays with money from their bank account via a debit card, it is still considered a credit card transaction, rather than an eftpos payment.</p>\n<p>The higher interchange fees involved with certain credit cards can mean that contactless payments end up costing merchants more than necessary, and some merchants have passed these costs on to customers via higher prices and/or surcharges.</p>\n<p>Least-cost routing involves processing contactless card payments through the lowest-cost payment system, whether that’s the eftpos or Visa/Mastercard network, thereby helping to reduce the cost to merchants and/or customers.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Learn more about interchange fees:</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Credit card interchange fee changes – winners and losers</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/articles/credit-card-interchange-fee-changes-winners-and-losers\">Read More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><span>Westpac chief product officer, Jim Tate, said that Australia had one of the highest adoption rates of credit cards in the world, and that least-cost routing should help to level the playing field for small businesses. </span></p>\n<p><span>Australian Retailers Association (ARA) executive director, Russell Zimmerman, voiced his support for Westpac’s decision to offer dual network routing, stating that according to McLean Roche Consulting, the current system is costing the Australian economy an estimated $558 million.</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Card surcharging to become a thing of the past</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Small businesses to start phasing out surcharges</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/credit-cards/news/small-businesses-start-phasing-surcharges\">Read Bristow","compliedAuthor":"55","content:encoded":"<p><span></span><span><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/westpac\">Westpac</a> has confirmed it plans to offer least-cost routing for contactless debit card payments, which could allow retailers to lower operating costs and pass the savings on to Australian shoppers. </span></p>\n<p><span>Last year, the Reserve Bank of Australia&#8217;s (RBA) Payment Systems Board recommended that regulations be put in place to ensure banks give merchants the ability to send tap-and-go payments from dual-network debit cards through the channel of their choice, if the banks had not already facilitated this recommendation by 1 April 2018.</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div around Australia automatically rout contactless card payments through payment networks owned by the likes of Visa and Mastercard.</p>\n<p>This means that even if a shopper pays with money from their bank account via a debit card, it is still considered a credit card transaction, rather than an eftpos payment.</p>\n<p>The higher interchange fees involved with certain credit cards can mean that contactless payments end up costing merchants more than necessary, and some merchants have passed these costs on to customers via higher prices and/or surcharges.</p>\n<p>Least-cost routing involves processing contactless card payments through the lowest-cost payment system, whether that’s the eftpos or Visa/Mastercard network, thereby helping to reduce the cost to merchants and/or customers.</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Learn more about interchange fees:</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Credit card Bendel","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/nab\">NAB</a> and ING are offering some of the lowest two-year fixed-rate mortgages on the market, although smaller lenders are also competing fiercely.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/nab\">NAB</a> is giving owner-occupiers the chance to fix for two years at 3.69 per cent (comparison rate 4.86 per cent) if they sign up for the Choice first home buyer special.</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Some rates go down, others go up</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Westpac changes its fixed-rate mortgages</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/westpac-changes-fixed-rate-mortgages\">Read More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ING has a slightly higher two-year fixed rate of 3.72 per cent (comparison rate 4.55 per cent) for its Orange Advantage home loan.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/scu\">SCU</a>, <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/greater-bank\">Greater Bank</a>, <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/newcastle-permanent\">Newcastle Permanent</a>, <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/teachers-mutual-bank\">Teachers Mutual Bank</a> and <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/companies/unicredit-wa\">UniBank</a> are all offering two-year fixed rates starting from 3.69 per cent (see table below).</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Interest rates on two-year fixed-rate mortgages have been quite stable over the past 12 months, according to an analysis of all the two-year loans on RateCity.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The average rate for owner-occupiers was 4.16 per cent at the end of May 2018 &#8211; the same rate recorded at the end of May 2017.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The average rate for investors rose from 4.39 per cent to 4.44 per cent during that time.</span></p>\n<div class=\"table-responsive\">\n<table class=\"table A property investment expert has revealed suburbs around Australia that are set to gentrify.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Research by Peter Koulizos, the chairman of Property Investment Professionals of Australia (PIPA), has identified 12 suburbs in four states:</span></p>\n<div class=\"table-responsive\">\n<table class=\"table #000000;\">Adelaide</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Thebarton</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">5031</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Adelaide</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">West Croydon</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">5008</span></td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Adelaide</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">Hindmarsh</span></td>\n<td><span style=\"color: #000000;\">5007</span></td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n</div>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said gentrification is continuing in capital cities across the country – the key is to buy in those locations early to make the most of the potential price upswing.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>If you had this knowledge a few decades ago, you would have bought in suburbs such as Balmain and Paddington in Sydney before they became highly sought-after and expensive,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Likewise, in Melbourne, where you would have invested in Richmond or Collingwood before they became really popular and pricey.<span>”</span></span></p>\n<p><img style=\"width: 100%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20171205132448/iStock-8276154041.jpg\" /></p>\n<h3>The four signs of gentrification</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos’ research found four key indicators when city suburbs are poised to gentrify:</span></p>\n<ol>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater decrease than the state average in people aged 18 years and under</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater increase than the state average in couples without children</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater increase than the state average in people that lived at a different address five years earlier</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater increase in the percentage of females working in professional occupations</span></li>\n</ol>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">When an inner suburb experiences an increase in childless couples and a decrease in children, it suggests younger adults are moving to areas that are close to universities and employment hubs, according to Mr Koulizos.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>They can&#8217;t afford to live in the ritzy eastern suburbs of Sydney, Melbourne or Adelaide, so they target the more affordable and gentrifying inner-western suburbs of these cities,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said another indicator of gentrification is when older long-term residents are replaced by younger new arrivals. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>It is often the case that before an area gentrifies it is full of older people who are still living in the houses they bought 50 years ago. As many of them are now on fixed incomes or pensions, they can&#8217;t afford to make substantial improvements to their homes, so in move the younger people,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Many of them work in professional jobs in the city, on relatively high incomes, no dependants and have a high disposable income and <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/how-much-can-i-borrow\">borrowing capacity</a>, so they have the ability to upgrade the period and character homes.<span>”</span></span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said the final sign of gentrification is an increase in the numbers of white-collar women, who have the funds to buy, renovate, upgrade or develop homes in the area.</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Small-deposit mortgages now harder to get</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Banks tighten the screws on home loans</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/banks-tighten-screws-small-deposit-mortgages\">Read More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>","category":["property","property investment","real estate"],"coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Nick Bendel","compliedAuthor":"39","content:encoded":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Looking to invest in the next Balmain or Collingwood? A property investment expert has revealed suburbs around Australia that are set to gentrify.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Research by Peter Koulizos, the chairman of Property Investment Professionals of Australia (PIPA), has identified 12 suburbs in four states:</span></p>\n<div class=\"table-responsive\">\n<table class=\"table became really popular and pricey.<span>”</span></span></p>\n<p><img style=\"width: 100%;\" class=\"aligncenter size-full wp-image-55347\" alt=\"istock_79305201_small5\" src=\"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20171205132448/iStock-8276154041.jpg\" /></p>\n<h3>The four signs of gentrification</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos’ research found four key indicators when city suburbs are poised to gentrify:</span></p>\n<ol>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater decrease than the state average in people aged 18 years and under</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">A greater increase than the state average in couples without children</span></li>\n<li according to Mr Koulizos.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>They can&#8217;t afford to live in the ritzy eastern suburbs of Sydney, Melbourne or Adelaide, so they target the more affordable and gentrifying inner-western suburbs of these cities,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said another indicator of gentrification is when older long-term residents are replaced by younger new arrivals. </span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span>“</span>It is often the case that before an area gentrifies it is full of older people who are still living in the houses they bought 50 years ago. As many of them are now on fixed incomes or pensions, they can&#8217;t afford to make substantial improvements to their homes, so in move the younger people,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Many of them work in professional jobs in the city, on relatively high incomes, no dependants and have a high disposable income and <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/how-much-can-i-borrow\">borrowing capacity</a>, so they have the ability to upgrade the period and character homes.<span>”</span></span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Koulizos said the final sign of gentrification is an increase in the numbers of white-collar women, who have the funds to buy, renovate, upgrade or develop homes in the area.</span></p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">Small-deposit mortgages now harder to get</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">Banks tighten the screws on home loans</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/banks-tighten-screws-small-deposit-mortgages\">Read More</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>","created_at":"1529719833","dc:creator":"Nick Bendel","description":"Looking to invest in the next Balmain or Collingwood? sees no reason to lift rates right now","type":"article","updated_at":"1529414461","url":"/home-loans/mortgage-news/rba-sees-no-reason-lift-rates-right-now","uses_markdown":"false"},{"SEO_Smart_Links":"[null,null,\"\",\"\",null]","_edit_last":"55","_edit_lock":"1529288549:55","_yoast_wpseo_metadesc":"New research from RateCity shows banks have put the brakes on lending to people with small deposits, slashing the number of mortgage products with a maximum loan-to-value ratio (LVR) of 95 per cent in the past three years. Fewer than a third (32 per cent) of home loans in the RateCity database now offer lending up to a maximum of 95 per cent of the value of the property.","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"home-loans","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Nick Bendel","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>New research from <a href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans\">RateCity</a> shows banks have put the brakes on lending to people with small deposits, slashing the number of mortgage products with a maximum loan-to-value ratio (LVR) of 95 per cent in the past three years.</p>\n<p>Fewer than a third (32 per cent) of home loans in the RateCity database now offer lending up to a maximum of 95 per cent of the value of the property.</p>\n<p>That’s down from 76 per cent of all loans on offer in early 2015, in line with lending guidelines by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, who want loans with small deposits to be the exception, rather than the rule.</p>\n<p>Sally Tindall, spokesperson at RateCity, said the banks were actively looking for deposits of 20 per cent, if not more.</p>\n<p>“For Australians battling to crack into the highly competitive home loan market, low-deposit loans have been a doorway in. But the rules have changed and now borrowers that might have been given the green light three years ago are starting to be turned away,” she said.</p>\n<p>RateCity research shows that upgrading from a 5 per cent deposit to a 20 per cent deposit on a $500,000 mortgage will require a buyer to stump up an extra $75,000 in cash.</p>\n<p>“These new LVR requirements will set a lot of potential buyers back, because they just don’t have access to that kind of money,&#8221; Ms Tindall said.</p>\n<p>“But the alternative is worse. Stretching yourself thin at record-low interest rates can be a recipe for disaster.</p>\n<p>“It’s been over seven years since we’ve experienced an <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\">RBA rate</a> hike and people have become complacent. These new LVR rules will sharpen the focus of those who are serious about securing housing finance.&#8221;</p>","category":["mortgage","mortgages"],"coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Nick Bendel","compliedAuthor":"18","content:encoded":"<p>New research from <a href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans\">RateCity</a> shows banks have put the brakes on lending to people with small deposits, slashing the number of mortgage products with a maximum loan-to-value ratio (LVR) of 95 per cent in the past three years.</p>\n<p>Fewer than a third (32 per cent) of home loans in the RateCity database now offer lending up to a maximum of 95 per cent of the value of the property.</p>\n<p>That’s down from 76 per cent of all loans on offer in early 2015, in line with lending guidelines by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, who want loans with small deposits to be the exception, rather than the rule.</p>\n<p>Sally Tindall, spokesperson at RateCity, said the banks were actively looking for deposits of 20 per cent, if not more.</p>\n<p>“For Australians battling to crack into the highly competitive home loan market, low-deposit loans have been a doorway in. But the rules have changed and now borrowers that might have been given the green light three years ago are starting to be turned away,” she said.</p>\n<p>RateCity research shows that upgrading from a 5 per cent deposit to a 20 per cent deposit on a $500,000 mortgage will require a buyer to stump up an extra $75,000 in cash.</p>\n<p>“These new LVR requirements will set a lot of potential buyers back, because they just don’t have access to that kind of money,&#8221; Ms Tindall said.</p>\n<p>“But the alternative is worse. Stretching yourself thin at record-low interest rates can be a recipe for disaster.</p>\n<p>“It’s been over seven years since we’ve experienced an <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"//www.ratecity.com.au/rba-cash-rate\">RBA rate</a> hike and people have become complacent. with the process expected to be completed by the end of 2019.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">If the REIA proposal is accepted, participating real estate agents will have to:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Pass “rigorous tests” to become recognised as a ‘professional’ real estate agent</span></li>\n<li style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Meet ongoing training standards</span></li>\n</ul>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Real estate agents would no longer be recognised as ‘professional’ agents if they class=\"breakout-body\">\n<p><span>A ‘Hotspot’ is an area with at least $150 million worth of residential building approved during the 2016/17 financial year, and a rate of population growth that is faster than the national average.</span></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h3><strong>National Top 20 Building and Population Hotspots</strong></h3>\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered Homebush Bay &#8211; Silverwater</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>NSW</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>358,252</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>8.0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<p style=\"text-align: right;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://hia.com.au/-/media/HIA-Website/Files/Media-Centre/Media-Releases/2018/national/melbourne-dominates-australia-housing-hotspots-list.ashx\">HIA.com.au</a></em></p>\n<p><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">This top 20 list of building growth areas shows that:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li>12 of the Top 20 Hotspots are located in Victoria;</li>\n<li>NSW contains 4 of the national Top 20;</li>\n<li>Four of the country’s top Hotspots are in Queensland.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>HIA’s Senior Economist, Shane Garrett stated that Melbourne “dominated this year’s HIA Hotspots Report, with 12 of Australia’s Top 20 building growth areas all located around Victoria’s capital”.</p>\n<blockquote><p><em>“The Mickleham-Yuroke area of Melbourne is Australia’s number one Hotspot, with population growth of 35.3 per cent during 2016/17 and $222.9 million in building approvals.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“With a large volume of work still to be commenced, no downturn evident in approvals, and population growth still exceeding 2 per cent, Melbourne and its surrounding areas are likely to produce many Hotspots for building activity going into 2019.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“Pimpana on the Gold Coast slipped to second place this year with Melbourne’s Cranbourne East area in third position nationally.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“The remarkable performance of Melbourne in this year’s Hotspots report demonstrates how well the circle of job creation, population growth and new home building can boost an economy.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“A number of Sydney’s Western and South Western suburbs are also on the move. From Leppington to Parramatta and Blacktown, the large pipeline of new housing will attract significant population growth.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“In Queensland, the South Eastern corner is the focus of activity. Population growth in the South East has accelerated over the past year, indicating that Queensland is starting to see solid employment gains.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“Coomera is also a regular on the Hotspots list, joined by South Brisbane where the apartment boom has resulted in significant approvals and population growth.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“Even in those parts of the country that are experiencing challenging economic conditions, there are some bright spots on the local housing map. We have identified Hotspots in all states and territories which are underpinned by robust levels of new home building and increases in population,”</em> concluded Shane Garrett.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">how do we solve housing affordability?</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">HIA says &#8220;keep building homes&#8221;</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/solve-housing-affordability\">Read More Now</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>","category":["hia","residential construction"],"coauthor_image":"//1.gravatar.com/avatar/4ee1f1fe2e93e77a62cef8feeaa4d72a?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Alex Ritchie","compliedAuthor":"55","content:encoded":"<p>Melbourne had the strongest market for building and population growth throughout 2018, according to the latest Housing Industry Association (HIA) Population & Residential Building Hotspots report.</p>\n<div class=\"breakout breakout-tip\">\n<div class=\"breakout-heading\">\n<p class=\"breakout-title\"><strong>What is a ‘Hotspot’?</strong></p>\n</div>\n<div class=\"breakout-body\">\n<p><span>A ‘Hotspot’ is an area with at least $150 million worth of residential building approved during the 2016/17 financial year, and a rate of population growth that is faster than the national average.</span></p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<h3><strong>National Top 20 Building and Population Hotspots</strong></h3>\n<table class=\"table table-striped table-bordered table-condensed table-hover\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Statistical Area </strong></p>\n<p><strong> </strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>State / Territory</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Residential Building Approved, 2016/17 ($&#8217;000)</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p><strong>Annual Population Growth Rate (%)</strong></p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p>1. Homebush Bay &#8211; Silverwater</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>NSW</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>358,252</p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<p>8.0</p>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n<p style=\"text-align: right;\"><em>Source: <a href=\"https://hia.com.au/-/media/HIA-Website/Files/Media-Centre/Media-Releases/2018/national/melbourne-dominates-australia-housing-hotspots-list.ashx\">HIA.com.au</a></em></p>\n<p><span style=\"text-decoration: underline;\">This top 20 list of building growth areas shows that:</span></p>\n<ul>\n<li>12 of the Top 20 Hotspots are located in Victoria;</li>\n<li>NSW contains 4 of the national Top 20;</li>\n<li>Four of the country’s top Hotspots are in Queensland.</li>\n</ul>\n<p>HIA’s Senior Economist, Shane Garrett stated that Melbourne “dominated this year’s HIA Hotspots Report, with 12 of Australia’s Top 20 building growth areas all located around Victoria’s capital”.</p>\n<blockquote><p><em>“The Mickleham-Yuroke area of Melbourne is Australia’s number one Hotspot, with population growth of 35.3 per cent during 2016/17 and $222.9 million in building approvals.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“With a large volume of work still to be commenced, no downturn evident in approvals, and population growth still exceeding 2 per cent, Melbourne and its surrounding areas are likely to produce many Hotspots for building activity going into 2019.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“Pimpana on the Gold Coast slipped to second place this year with Melbourne’s Cranbourne East area in third position nationally.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“The remarkable performance of Melbourne in this year’s Hotspots report demonstrates how well the circle of job creation, population growth and new home building can boost an economy.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“A number of Sydney’s Western and South Western suburbs are also on the move. From Leppington to Parramatta and Blacktown, the large pipeline of new housing will attract significant population growth.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“In Queensland, the South Eastern corner is the focus of activity. Population growth in the South East has accelerated over the past year, indicating that Queensland is starting to see solid employment gains.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“Coomera is also a regular on the Hotspots list, joined by South Brisbane where the apartment boom has resulted in significant approvals and population growth.</em><em> </em></p>\n<p><em>“Even in those parts of the country that are experiencing challenging economic conditions, there are some bright spots on the local housing map. We have identified Hotspots in all states and territories which are underpinned by robust levels of new home building and increases in population,”</em> concluded Shane Garrett.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div class=\"col-sm-7\">\n<h6 id=\"btn-subtitle-test\">how do we solve housing affordability?</h6>\n<h3 id=\"btn-title-test\">HIA says &#8220;keep building homes&#8221;</h3>\n</div>\n<div class=\"col-sm-5 text-right\"><a class=\"btn btn-primary btn-lg\" id=\"btn-test\" href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans/mortgage-news/solve-housing-affordability\">Read More Now</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>","created_at":"1528975356","dc:creator":"Alex Ritchie","description":"Melbourne had the strongest market for building and population growth throughout 2018, according to the latest Housing Industry Association (HIA) Population &#38; Residential Building Hotspots report. Hay","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>Today’s ABS housing finance figures show a continued fall in home loan lending as the fallout from the banking Royal Commission sets in.</p>\n<p>ABS data released today shows a 0.9 per cent drop in investor lending and an 0.2 per cent in all lending from the previous month, according to the seasonally adjusted figures from the ABS.</p>\n<p>While these falls are relatively minor, it shows a continued slide in home loan lending. Investors have dropped 15 per cent over the year, while the total lending figures have dropped 3.2 per cent annually. </p>\n<p><a href=\"https://www.ratecity.com.au/home-loans\">RateCity</a> spokesperson Sally Tindall said today’s figures were further evidence of the cooling of the Sydney and Melbourne housing markets, fuelled by the tightening of banks’ lending criteria.</p>\n<p>“APRA has been very clever in motivating the banks to improve their serviceability policies,” she said.</p>\n<p>“Findings from the Royal Commission have also had a major impact on loan application processes, with increased scrutiny on paperwork at every step in the process.</p>\n<p>“If you’re looking for a home loan, it’s now vitally important to get all your ducks in a row before applying,” she said.</p>\n<p><strong>APRA’s serviceability guidelines include:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li>interest rate floors of above 7 per cent</li>\n<li>interest rate buffers of at least 2 per cent.</li>\n<li>greater scrutiny of high debt to income borrowers and</li>\n<li>the implementation of maximum debt to income levels.</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Tips for assessing how much you can borrow:</strong></p>\n<ul>\n<li>Make sure you have a decent deposit of at least 20 per cent</li>\n<li>Check you can comfortably service your mortgage if rates hit 8 per cent.</li>\n<li>Be prepared for ASIC is running a campaign to help Australians understand that credit repair and debt management firms can charge high fees - and sometimes give nothing in return.","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"personal-loans","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Nick Bendel","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><b></b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Australia’s financial services regulator has warned consumers to be wary of companies that claim they can fix poor credit ratings.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ASIC is running a campaign to help Australians understand that credit repair and debt management firms can charge high fees &#8211; and sometimes give nothing in return.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">These companies “often fail to fix credit and debt issues, which can leave people in a worse financial situation”, according to ASIC.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ASIC deputy chair Peter Kell said there are free services, such as the </span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.ndh.org.au/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">National Debt Helpline</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, which can help Australians fix credit reports or resolve their debt problems.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Consumers experiencing money or debt problems don’t need to put themselves under further financial stress by paying high fees to firms providing credit repair and debt solution services,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“If people are having difficulty obtaining loans because of an incorrect default listing on their credit report, there are actions they can take that are free of charge to have it corrected.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“If you think you have had a credit default wrongly listed against you, contact the creditor and ask for it to be removed. If you aren’t satisfied with the response, you receive you can contact the relevant dispute resolution service for help.”</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Kell said consumers should consider alternative services, like financial counselling, before engaging a debt solutions firm.</span></p>","category":["ASIC","bad credit"],"coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Nick Bendel","compliedAuthor":"44","content:encoded":"<p><b></b><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Australia’s financial services regulator has warned consumers to be wary of companies that claim they can fix poor credit ratings.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ASIC is running a campaign to help Australians understand that credit repair and debt management firms can charge high fees &#8211; and sometimes give nothing in return.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">These companies “often fail to fix credit and debt issues, which can leave people in a worse financial situation”, according to ASIC.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ASIC deputy chair Peter Kell said there are free services, such as the </span><a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://www.ndh.org.au/\"><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">National Debt Helpline</span></a><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">, which can help Australians fix credit reports or resolve their debt problems.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“Consumers experiencing money or debt problems don’t need to put themselves under further financial stress by paying high fees to firms providing credit repair and debt solution services,” he said.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“If people are having difficulty obtaining loans because of an incorrect default listing on their credit report, there are actions they can take that are free of charge to have it corrected.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“If you think you have had a credit default wrongly listed against you, contact the creditor and ask for it to be removed. If you aren’t satisfied with the response, you receive you can contact the relevant dispute resolution service for help.”</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Mr Kell said consumers should consider alternative services, like financial counselling, before engaging a debt solutions firm.</span></p>","created_at":"1528453317","dc:creator":"Nick Bendel","description":"Australia’s financial services regulator has warned consumers to be wary of companies that claim they can fix poor credit ratings. These companies “often fail to fix credit and &#8230; <a href=\"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/debt-management-firms-can-leave-people-worse-financial-situation/\" class=\"more-link\">Continue reading<span class=\"screen-reader-text\"> \"Debt management firms ‘can leave people in a worse financial situation’\"</span></a>","exclusive_to_partner":"false","faq_description":null,"guid":{"$t":"http://content.ratecity.com.au/?post_type=ratecity_article&p=76623","isPermaLink":"false"},"has_video":"false","header_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20171108124446/get-out-of-debt-750x420.jpg","id":76623,"link":"http://content.ratecity.com.au/ratecity_article/debt-management-firms-can-leave-people-worse-financial-situation/","media_release":null,"overallRating":null,"page_header":null,"page_subheader":null,"partner_name":null,"post_id":"76623","pubDate":"Fri, 08 Jun 2018 00:21:57 +0000","publish_until":null,"question":null,"quote":null,"readingTime":2,"result_name":null,"short_description":"Australia’s financial services regulator has warned consumers to be wary of companies that claim they can fix poor credit ratings.","slider_data":[],"slug":"debt-management-firms-can-leave-people-worse-financial-situation","status":"publish","supplierReference":null,"supplier_reference":null,"thumbnail_image_url":"//production-content-assets.ratecity.com.au/20171108124446/get-out-of-debt-350x500.jpg","title":"Debt management firms ‘can leave people in a worse financial situation’","type":"article","updated_at":"1528453329","url":"/personal-loans/news/debt-management-firms-can-leave-people-worse-financial-situation","uses_markdown":"false"},{"SEO_Smart_Links":"[null,null,\"\",\"\",null]","_edit_last":"55","_edit_lock":"1526516032:55","_yoast_wpseo_metadesc":"The Federal Court of Australia has ordered a $2 million penalty against Thorn Australia Pty Ltd's Radio Rentals for contravening its responsible lending obligations. The court found that “Thorn failed to make the necessary inquiries and take steps to verify the financial situation of its customers, and failed to conduct a proper assessment of the suitability of the leases it provided,” according to ASIC, Australia’s financial services regulator.","article_template":"default","article_type":"news","article_vertical":"personal-loans","attachments":null,"author_description":null,"author_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","author_job_title":null,"author_name":"Nick Bendel","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The Federal Court of Australia has ordered a $2 million penalty against Thorn Australia Pty Ltd&#8217;s Radio Rentals for contravening its responsible lending obligations.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The court found that “Thorn failed to make the necessary inquiries and take steps to verify the financial situation of its customers, and failed to conduct a proper assessment of the suitability of the leases it provided,” according to ASIC, Australia’s financial services regulator.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">This comes after ASIC investigated Thorn’s leasing practices, particularly whether people signing up to the leases had the capacity to pay.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The breaches relate to more than 270,000 leases signed between January 2012 and May 2015.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Thorn will also have to pay ASIC&#8217;s court and investigation costs of $240,000.</span></p>\n<h3>Business also has to make $20m in refund payments</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In January 2018, ASIC announced a package of regulatory outcomes against Thorn&#8217;s consumer leasing businesses, Radio Rentals, RR and Rentlo Reinvented, to “address past poor conduct and protect future customers”.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">This included $6.1 million in refunds to customers and write-offs of default fees, and an additional $13.8 million in customer refunds of excess lease payments.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Radio Rentals is providing refunds for affected customers as part of its enforceable undertaking to ASIC, according to the regulator.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Radio Rentals has until 7 November to contact all customers who are eligible for a refund or write-off.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ASIC deputy chair Peter Kell said the Federal Court’s penalty against Thorn reinforced the need to uphold high standards of conduct in the consumer leasing industry.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“The law requires lenders to verify a consumer’s financial situation to make sure that consumers are not being put into unaffordable loans or leases,” he said.</span></p>","category":"ASIC","coauthor_image":"//2.gravatar.com/avatar/861aca098d6becadbbfb0ed38816e1d2?s=96&d=mm&r=g","coauthor_name":"Nick Bendel","compliedAuthor":"44","content:encoded":"<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The Federal Court of Australia has ordered a $2 million penalty against Thorn Australia Pty Ltd&#8217;s Radio Rentals for contravening its responsible lending obligations.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The court found that “Thorn failed to make the necessary inquiries and take steps to verify the financial situation of its customers, and failed to conduct a proper assessment of the suitability of the leases it provided,” according to ASIC, Australia’s financial services regulator.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">This comes after ASIC investigated Thorn’s leasing practices, particularly whether people signing up to the leases had the capacity to pay.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">The breaches relate to more than 270,000 leases signed between January 2012 and May 2015.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Thorn will also have to pay ASIC&#8217;s court and investigation costs of $240,000.</span></p>\n<h3>Business also has to make $20m in refund payments</h3>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">In January 2018, ASIC announced a package of regulatory outcomes against Thorn&#8217;s consumer leasing businesses, Radio Rentals, RR and Rentlo Reinvented, to “address past poor conduct and protect future customers”.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">This included $6.1 million in refunds to customers and write-offs of default fees, and an additional $13.8 million in customer refunds of excess lease payments.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Radio Rentals is providing refunds for affected customers as part of its enforceable undertaking to ASIC, according to the regulator.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">Radio Rentals has until 7 November to contact all customers who are eligible for a refund or write-off.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">ASIC deputy chair Peter Kell said the Federal Court’s penalty against Thorn reinforced the need to uphold high standards of conduct in the consumer leasing industry.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"font-weight: 400;\">“The law requires lenders to verify a consumer’s financial situation to make sure that consumers are not being put into unaffordable loans or Bendel","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>Bankruptcies, debt agreements and personal insolvency agreements all rose in the final quarter of 2017, according to new data.</p>\n<p>The Australian Financial Security Authority (AFSA) has reported that there were 7,578 new personal insolvencies in the December quarter – up 7.4 per cent on the previous year.</p>\n<p>Breaking down the numbers, those 7,578 insolvencies included:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>4,029 bankruptcies (up 1.3 per cent)</li>\n<li>3,500 debt agreements (up 15.3 per cent)</li>\n<li>49 personal insolvency agreements (up 14.0 per cent)</li>\n</ul>\n<p>The December quarter was also the 10th consecutive quarter in which debt agreements increased in year-on-year terms.</p>\n<div>\n<div class=\"link-bar\">\n<div Bendel","author_twitter":null,"body":"<p>Hallmark General Insurance Company, trading as Latitude Insurance, will provide refunds of about $1.1 million to 905 customers.</p>\n<p>Latitude “mis-sold consumer credit insurance (CCI) with Latitude personal loans”, <a target=\"_blank\" href=\"http://asic.gov.au/about-asic/media-centre/find-a-media-release/2017-releases/17-457mr-latitude-insurance-refunds-almost-11-million-for-poor-consumer-credit-insurance-sales-and-claims-handling\">according to ASIC</a>, the financial services regulator.</p>\n<p>Latitude also “incorrectly denied claims on CCI policies sold with Latitude and other credit cards”.</p>\n<p>Consumer credit insurance is an add-on insurance that helps borrowers meet repayments if they die, suffer a traumatic illness, or become disabled or unemployed.</p>\n<p>ASIC said that Latitude identified and reported to the regulator that, between October 2011 and June 2014, it sold involuntary unemployment insurance to personal loan customers who were ineligible to claim because they did not work the required minimum 20 hours per week.</p>\n<p>Latitude also identified that, between May 2014 and February 2017, its partly automated claims assessment process had incorrectly denied claims to credit card CCI customers, because it failed to properly apply the exclusion definition of &#8216;casual employment’.</p>\n<p>In response, ASIC said Latitude would:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Refund premiums and interest to personal loan involuntary unemployment insurance customers who were ineligible to claim</li>\n<li>Pay claim amounts and interest to credit card CCI customers whose claims had been incorrectly denied</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Latitude will be contacting eligible customers. Latitude customers with questions or concerns should contact the company on 1800 800 230.</p>\n<p>In August, ASIC announced that <a class=\"rc-keyword\" target=\"_blank\"
